Analysing the results¶
Introduction


The table above provides a statistical summary of the fields in the collection listingsAndReviews_HW2 including the count of documents, distinct values, mean, minimum, and maximum values for each field.


    

  • From the analysis, we can verify that most fields are consistent with our expectations, with the exception of a few fields: maximum_nights, bathrooms, bedrooms, and price.
    • 





maximum_nights


    

  • As shown in the results above, the maximum value for the field maximum_nights is extremely high — specifically, $2\;147\;483\;647$. While we know with certainty that no guest will ever book a stay for this many nights, this value appears in the dataset.
      

    • After reviewing Airbnb’s official guidelines (Source: https://www.airbnb.pt/help/article/880?), it is confirmed that hosts have full freedom to define any number for the maximum_nights field. Therefore, such high values are permitted by Airbnb.
      • 

    • It is likely that some hosts intentionally set extremely high values to signal that there is effectively no maximum stay limit. These values, although unusually large, are still valid in the context of Airbnb’s platform.
      • 

    • While these values are valid, in a different context — such as modeling guest behavior or predicting average stay length — they could be treated as statistical outliers. However, since that is not the goal of our current work, we will not perform any data cleaning or transformation for these records.
      • 

    

    • 



bathrooms


    

  • As shown in the results above, the minimum value for the field bathrooms is $0$. In some cases this value makes total sense (Source: https://community.withairbnb.com/t5/Advice-on-your-space/bathroom-classification/m-p/1652130) while in others it doesn't.
      

    • Properties with types like *Camper/RV, Tent* and *Shared Room* may not have private bathrooms indicating that the value $0$ makes sense. On the other hand property types like *Apartment* and House are unlikely to have $0$ bathrooms.
      • 

    

    • 



bedrooms


    

  • As shown in the results above, the minimum value for the field bedrooms is $0$.
      

    • For properties with types like *Apartment* that are Studios or Lofts this value makes sense potentially reflecting that they share a single open space.
      • 

    • On the other hand property types like *House* are unlikely to have $0$ bedrooms.
      • 

    

    • 



price


    

  • As shown in the results above, the maximum value for the field price is $48\;842.0$. The field price indicates the price per night for a listing.
      

    • This value is extremely high and seems unrealistic for a single night stay.
      • 

    • It is possible that this value is a result of data entry errors or outliers in the dataset.
      • 

    • To further investigate, we can check the distribution of prices and identify any potential outliers.
      • 

    

    • 























maximum_nights¶


















In [221]:






# Check cases with 'maximum_nights' more that 1 000 000
large_maximum_nights = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({"maximum_nights": {"$gt": 1_000_000}})
for doc in large_maximum_nights:
    print(f"Document with _id: {doc['_id']} has maximum_nights: {doc['maximum_nights']:<20} | Host URL: {doc['host_url']}")

























Document with _id: 10911771 has maximum_nights: 2147483647           | Host URL: https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/52473150
Document with _id: 19550563 has maximum_nights: 1234567890           | Host URL: https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/137344895
Document with _id: 6357527 has maximum_nights: 2147483647           | Host URL: https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/18762837
Document with _id: 744242 has maximum_nights: 2147483647           | Host URL: https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/4334558

























bathrooms¶


















In [222]:






# Number of listings where number of bathrooms is 0
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.count_documents({"bathrooms": 0})





















Out[222]:




14
























    

  • There are a total of $14$ listings with $0$ bathrooms. We will investigate the property types of these listings to see if they are valid.
    • 



















In [223]:






# Check cases with 'bathrooms' = 0
cursor = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({"bathrooms": 0}, projection={"_id": 0, "bathrooms": 1, "property_type": 1, "host_url":1})
for doc in cursor:
    print(doc)

























{'property_type': 'House', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/6250742'}
{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/27201583'}
{'property_type': 'Hostel', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/30098437'}
{'property_type': 'Camper/RV', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/36714324'}
{'property_type': 'Serviced apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/14861546'}
{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/51198195'}
{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/219415974'}
{'property_type': 'Bed and breakfast', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/98135964'}
{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/221016656'}
{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/226980154'}
{'property_type': 'House', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/283136'}
{'property_type': 'House', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/34682013'}
{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/494228'}
{'property_type': 'Serviced apartment', 'bathrooms': Decimal128('0.0'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/38468501'}

























    

  • As we can from the results above, there are some listings with $0$ bathrooms with property types that do not make sense (e.g *House, Apartment*, etc.).
      

    • To further investigate, we would need more information about each listings, access to the databases's metadata and to the host_url (links to the listings don't seem to work).
      • 

    • Hence no changes will be made
      • 

    

    • 























bedrooms¶


















In [224]:






# Count listings with 0 bedrooms
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.count_documents({"bedrooms": 0})





















Out[224]:




496
























    

  • As we can see there a total of $496$ listings with $0$ bedrooms.
      

    • As they represent almost $10\%$ of total listings we will analyse the distribution of property types with $0$ bedrooms to understand which are correctly described with $0$ bedrooms and which aren't
      • 

    

    • 



















In [225]:






# Check distribution of property types with 0 bedrooms
pipeline = [
    {"$match": {"bedrooms": 0}},
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$property_type",
        "count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    {"$sort": {"count": -1}}  
]

results = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
for doc in results:
    print(f"{doc['_id']}: {doc['count']}")

























Apartment: 305
Condominium: 52
Loft: 33
Serviced apartment: 25
House: 19
Guest suite: 14
Guesthouse: 9
Bed and breakfast: 6
Boutique hotel: 5
Other: 4
Townhouse: 3
Cottage: 3
Hostel: 3
Cabin: 3
Camper/RV: 2
Tiny house: 2
Bungalow: 2
Pension (South Korea): 1
Aparthotel: 1
Resort: 1
Farm stay: 1
Hotel: 1
Casa particular (Cuba): 1

























    

  • As we can from the results above, there are some listings with $0$ bedrooms with property types that do not make sense (e.g *House* etc.).
      

    • As explained in the case of bathrooms, to further investigate these cases, we would need more information about each listings, access to the databases's metadata and to the host_url (links to the listings don't seem to work).
      • 

    • Hence no changes will be made
      • 

    

    • 























price¶


















In [226]:






# Find properties that have a price equal to 48842.0 and project _id, property_type, price and host_url
cursor = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({"price": 48842.0}, projection={"_id": 0, "property_type": 1, "price": 1, "host_url":1})
for doc in cursor:
    print(doc)

























{'property_type': 'Apartment', 'price': Decimal128('48842.00'), 'host_url': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/118695718'}





















In [227]:






# Distribution of prices across multiple price ranges (bins)
# Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/bucket/

bins = [0, 100, 500, 1000, 5000, 10000, 20000, 50000]
labels = ["0-100", "101-500", "501-1000", "1001-5000", "5001-10000", "10001-20000", "20001-50000"]
pipeline = [
    {"$bucket": {
        "groupBy": "$price",
        "boundaries": bins,
        "default": "50001+",  # Default bucket for values above the last boundary
        "output": {
            "count": {"$sum": 1},
            "average_price": {"$avg": "$price"}
        }
    }}
]
results = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
for doc in results:
    if doc['_id'] == "50001+":  # Handle the default bucket
        price_range = "50001+"
    else:
        # Map the bucket index to the corresponding label
        index = bins.index(doc['_id'])
        price_range = labels[index]
    
    avg_price = float(str(doc['average_price']))  # Convert Decimal128 to string, then to float
    print(f"Price Range: {price_range}, Count: {doc['count']}, Average Price: {avg_price:.2f}")

























Price Range: 0-100, Count: 2181, Average Price: 59.24
Price Range: 101-500, Count: 2627, Average Price: 213.11
Price Range: 501-1000, Count: 528, Average Price: 686.03
Price Range: 1001-5000, Count: 207, Average Price: 1724.65
Price Range: 5001-10000, Count: 6, Average Price: 6149.83
Price Range: 10001-20000, Count: 5, Average Price: 10910.80
Price Range: 20001-50000, Count: 1, Average Price: 48842.00

























    

  • From the results above, we can see that we only have $6$ listings with price over $10\;000$ per night
      

    • These most likely correspond to outliers or luxury listings.
      • 

    • Since we lack the metadata, working host_url links to these properties to determine if they are valid, we will not remove them.
      • 

    

    • 























number_of_reviews¶


















In [228]:






# Check if 'number_of_reviews' is equal to the length of 'reviews' array
pipeline = [
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 1,                                                       # Exclude _id from output
        "number_of_reviews": 1,                                         # Include number_of_reviews field
        "reviews_length": {"$size": "$reviews"}                         # Calculate length of reviews array
    }},
    {"$match": {
        "$expr": {"$ne": ["$number_of_reviews", "$reviews_length"]}     # Check if number_of_reviews is not equal to length of reviews array
    }}
]
results = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
print(f"\033[1mNumber of documents with mismatch: \033[0m {len(results)} ({len(results)/db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.count_documents({}) * 100:.2f}%)")
pprint(results)
# for doc in results:
#     print(f"Number of reviews: {doc['number_of_reviews']}, Reviews array length: {doc['reviews_length']}")

In [229]:






# Check specific document with _id = 17951038
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find_one({"_id": "17951038"}, projection={"_id": 0, "reviews": 1, "number_of_reviews": 1, "reviews_length": {"$size": "$reviews"}})





















Out[229]:




{'number_of_reviews': 100, 'reviews': [], 'reviews_length': 0}
























    

  • We noticed that $245$ ($4.41\%$) listings have a number_of_reviews that doesn’t match the actual number of reviews in the reviews array. For now, we’re not doing anything about it because this field is probably just a leftover helper or display field from the past. Since it’s not causing any issues and fixing it would take extra time and processing, we’re choosing to leave it as is. If it ever becomes important later, we can clean it up in the background without affecting the system.
    

    • 

  • Additionally, due to the lack of metadata, we don't know if this mismatch is due to a problem during the web scraping process or due to an out of sync issue.
    

    • 























review_scores_rating¶

# Check all cases with 'review_scores_rating' more that 10
list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({'review_scores_rating': {"$gt": 10}},      # Query to find documents with 'review_scores_rating' > 10
                                    {'_id': 1, 'review_scores_rating': 1})      # Projection to include only '_id' and 'review_scores_rating'
     )[:10]  # Display first 10 documents with 'review_scores_rating' > 10

[{'_id': '10006546', 'review_scores_rating': 89},

 {'_id': '10021707', 'review_scores_rating': 100},
 {'_id': '1003530', 'review_scores_rating': 94},
 {'_id': '10038496', 'review_scores_rating': 98},
 {'_id': '10047964', 'review_scores_rating': 100},
 {'_id': '10051164', 'review_scores_rating': 80},

 {'_id': '10059872', 'review_scores_rating': 100},
 {'_id': '10083468', 'review_scores_rating': 97}]




















In [231]:






print(f"\033[1mNumber of documents with 'review_scores_rating' greater than 10:\033[0m {len(list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({'review_scores_rating': {'$gt': 10}})))}")

























Number of documents with 'review_scores_rating' greater than 10: 4081





















In [232]:






# Normalize 'review_scores_rating' to be between 0 and 10
# We consider that the range of all values is between 0 and 100, so we divide by 10 to normalize the values
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.update_many(
    {},
    # Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/divide/
    [{"$set": {"review_scores_rating": {"$divide": ["$review_scores_rating", 10]}}}]
)

# Check all cases with 'review_scores_rating' more that 10
list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({'review_scores_rating': {"$gt": 10}}, {'_id': 1, 'review_scores_rating': 1}))





















Out[232]:




[]




















In [233]:






# Check if 'review_scores_rating' is decimal after the change
review_scores_rating_type = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    # Only consider documents where the field exists
    {"$match": {"review_scores_rating": {"$exists": True}}},
    
    # Group by the BSON type of the field
    {"$group": {"_id": {"$type": "$review_scores_rating"}}},
    
    # Project the type name 
    {"$project": {"_id": 0, "BSONType": "$_id"}}
])
print(f"Data type of 'review_scores_rating': {list(review_scores_rating_type)}")

























Data type of 'review_scores_rating': [{'BSONType': 'double'}, {'BSONType': 'null'}]

























    

  • Analysis: The review_scores_rating field shows values up to 100, while other review_scores_* fields (checkin, cleanliness, etc.) are consistently between 0-10. This suggests review_scores_rating uses a different scale (0-100).
    

    • 

  • Decision & Transformation:
    

      

    • We applied data normalization to the review_scores_rating field by dividing its value by $10$, because its range ($0-100$) was inconsistent with other review scores ($0-10$). Unlike the other scores, this one will be kept in decimal format after normalization, in order to preserve more detailed information. We expect consistent scaling across all review score metrics, enabling meaningful calculation of averages (as required in Q9).
      • 

    

    • 



The verification query confirms that no review_scores_rating values are now greater than 10.






















amenities¶


















In [234]:






# Check if 'amenities' only appears in the array once
cursor = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({"amenities": {"$exists": True}})
for doc in cursor:
    if len(doc['amenities']) != len(set(doc['amenities'])):
        print(f"Duplicate amenities found in document with _id: {doc['_id']}")
        break

# Check 'amenities' for duplicates
pprint(sorted(list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({"_id": "1001265"}, {"amenities": 1}))[0]['amenities']))

In [235]:






# Remove duplicates from 'amenities' array
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.update_many(
    {},
    [{"$set": {
        "amenities": {"$setUnion": ["$amenities", []]}  # Remove duplicates
    }}]
)

# Check 'amenities' for duplicates again

host_verifications¶


















In [236]:






# Check if 'host_verifications' only appears in the array once
cursor = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({"host_verifications": {"$exists": True}})
len_host_verifications_duplicates = 0
for doc in cursor:
    if len(doc['host_verifications']) != len(set(doc['host_verifications'])):
        print(f"Duplicate host_verifications found in document with _id: {doc['_id']}")
        len_host_verifications_duplicates += 1
if len_host_verifications_duplicates > 0:
    print(f"\033[1mTotal documents with duplicate host_verifications: {len_host_verifications_duplicates}\033[0m")
else:
    print("No duplicate \033[1mhost_verifications\033[0m found")

























No duplicate host_verifications found

























transactions¶
    

  • We want to check the number of transactions registered before Airbnb was founded in 11 August 2008 (Source: https://www.airbnb.pt/about/about-us & https://www.businessofapps.com/data/airbnb-statistics/).
    • 



















In [237]:






# Date of foundation of Airbnb - 11 August 2008
airbnb_foundation_date = datetime(2008, 8, 11)

# Check if 'transactions.transactions.date' is before the foundation date
query = {
    "transactions.transactions": {
        "$elemMatch": {
            "date": {"$lt": airbnb_foundation_date}
        }
    }
}

# Count documents with transactions before the foundation date
count_before_foundation = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.count_documents(query)
print(f"\033[1mNumber of transactions before Airbnb's foundation date:\033[0m {count_before_foundation} ({count_before_foundation / total_docs:.2%})\033[1m of all documents\033[0m")

























Number of transactions before Airbnb's foundation date: 5467 (98.42%) of all documents





















In [238]:






# Pipeline to count the total number of transactions in the collection
pipeline_total = [
    {"$match": {"transactions.transactions": {"$exists": True, "$ne": []}}},
    {"$unwind": "$transactions.transactions"},
    {"$group": {"_id": None, "totalTransactions": {"$sum": 1}}}
]
total_result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline_total))
total_transactions = total_result[0]["totalTransactions"] if total_result else 0

# Pipeline to count transactions with a date before the foundation date
pipeline_before = [
    {"$match": {"transactions.transactions": {"$exists": True, "$ne": []}}},
    {"$unwind": "$transactions.transactions"},
    {"$match": {"transactions.transactions.date": {"$lt": airbnb_foundation_date}}},
    {"$group": {"_id": None, "countBefore": {"$sum": 1}}}
]
before_result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline_before))
count_before = before_result[0]["countBefore"] if before_result else 0

# Calculate the percentage of transactions that occurred before the foundation date
percentage = (count_before / total_transactions * 100) if total_transactions > 0 else 0

print(f"\033[1mNumber of transactions before Airbnb's foundation date:\033[0m {count_before} ({percentage:.2f}%)")

























Number of transactions before Airbnb's foundation date: 110837 (35.63%)

























    

  • Approximately $35.63\%$ of the transactions were performed before Airbnb’s foundation date. This significant proportion indicates that these records represent a considerable amount of historical data, and removing them could result in the loss of valuable information. Additionally, the lack of metadata or context for these transactions makes it difficult to determine their relevance or accuracy.
    • 



















In [239]:






# Verify that each transaction occurs within the 'bucket_start_date' and 'bucket_end_date'
pipeline = [
    {
        "$project": {
            "listing_id": 1,
            "BucketStart": "$transactions.bucket_start_date",
            "BucketEnd": "$transactions.bucket_end_date",
            "OutOfRangeTransactions": {
                "$filter": {
                    "input": "$transactions.transactions",
                    "as": "t",
                    "cond": {
                        "$or": [
                            { "$lt": ["$$t.date", "$transactions.bucket_start_date"] },
                            { "$gt": ["$$t.date", "$transactions.bucket_end_date"] }
                        ]
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    },
    # Only return documents with at least one out-of-range transaction
    {"$match": { "OutOfRangeTransactions.0": { "$exists": True } }}
]

# Execute the pipeline
out_of_range_docs = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
print(f"\033[1mNumber of transactions within the specified date range:\033[0m {len(out_of_range_docs)} \033[1mtransactions\033[0m ({len(out_of_range_docs) / total_docs:.2%} of all documents)")

























Number of transactions within the specified date range: 0 transactions (0.00% of all documents)

























Invalid Dates¶


















In [240]:






# Check if 'last_scraped' < 'last_review' (Invalid data)
invalid_dates = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({
    "$expr": {
        "$lt": ["$last_scraped", "$last_review"]
    }
})
if len(list(invalid_dates)) >  0:
    for doc in invalid_dates:
        print(f"Document with _id: {doc['_id']} has last_scraped: {doc['last_scraped']} < last_review: {doc['last_review']}")
else:
    print("No documents found with last_scraped < last_review.")

























No documents found with last_scraped < last_review.





















In [241]:






# Check if 'first_review' > 'last_review' (Invalid data)
invalid_dates = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({
    "$expr": {
        "$gt": ["$first_review", "$last_review"]
    }
})
if len(list(invalid_dates)) > 0:
    for doc in invalid_dates:
        print(f"Document with _id: {doc['_id']} has first_review: {doc['first_review']} > last_review: {doc['last_review']}")
else:
    print("No documents found with first_review > last_review.")

























No documents found with first_review > last_review.





















In [242]:






# Check if 'first_review' < 'transactions.transactions.date' (Invalid data)
invalid_dates = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find({
    "$expr": {
        "$lt": ["$first_review", {"$arrayElemAt": ["$transactions.transactions.date", 0]}]
    }
})
if len(list(invalid_dates)) > 0:
    for doc in invalid_dates:
        print(f"Document with _id: {doc['_id']} has first_review: {doc['first_review']} < transactions.transactions.date: {doc['transactions']['transactions'][0]['date']}")
else:
    print("No documents found with first_review < transactions.transactions.date.")















































📚 1.5 | Data Model Adjustments¶






















Three stage approach for data model and final schema design


    

  1. Workload stage
    2. 

  2. Relationship assessment
    3. 

  3. Patterns
    4. 











Based on the Workload, Relationships, and Patterns analysis, we will now implement the new schema design by creating separate collections for Hosts, Reviews, and Transactions, and restructuring the Listings collection.


Overall Strategy: Move large, unbounded, or independently accessed data (reviews, host details, transactions) out of the main listing document into their own collections, using references (Host_ID, Listing_ID, Reviewer_ID) to link them.






















1. Workload Stage¶


















In [243]:






# Determine total number of documents and total size
total_documents = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.count_documents({})

stats = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.database.command("collstats", db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.name)
total_size = stats["size"]  # Total document data size in bytes
total_size_gb = total_size / (1024 ** 3)

print(f"\033[1mTotal documents in the collection 'listingsAndReviews_HW2':\033[0m {total_documents}")
print(f"\033[1mTotal size of the collection 'listingsAndReviews_HW2':\033[0m      {total_size} bytes ({total_size_gb:.3f} GB)")

























Total documents in the collection 'listingsAndReviews_HW2': 5555
Total size of the collection 'listingsAndReviews_HW2':      108183825 bytes (0.101 GB)

























🧠 Workload Stage Summary¶






#
Step / Question
What it Entails
Entities Involved






1
Assess Data Size
Determine current collection volume and size
listingsAndReviews_HW2




2a
Most Common Use Case
Show property info to customers (core details + sample reviews)
Listings, Reviews




2b (Q7)
Unique amenities list for host registration
Show all unique amenities; rarely changes
Listings, Amenities (New)




2c (Q8)
Top 20 reviewers and fast review count lookup
Rank reviewers and return count per reviewer
Reviews, Reviewers (New)




2d (Q9)
Average of review scores (dynamic metrics)
Compute average across all review metrics
Listings, Review_Scores (Subdoc)




2e (Q10)
Avg transaction value per property for time period
Time-based aggregation on transactions
Transactions (New), Listings




2f (Q11)
Summary page of top 10 cities + top listings
Show city-level stats and example listings
Listings, Reviews, CitySummary (New)












Note: All the operations that we will do are mostly reads, but in real-world cenarios, *AirBnB* would have to do a lot of writes as well. So, we will try to optimize the database for both reads and writes.
























2. Relationships Assessment Stage¶
    

  1. Identify which entities are related
    2. 

  2. Measure quantity of related data (1:1, 1:N, N:N)
    3. 

  3. Decide whether to embed data or reference  it
      

    • Embed for fast reads & tightly coupled data
      • 

    • Reference for flexibility & loosely coupled data
      • 

    

    4. 























🔗 Relationships Phase Table (with Correct Embed/Reference Direction)¶






Entities
Relationship Type
Cardinality
Embed or Reference?
Reasoning
Context in Project






Listings
Hosts
Listing has one Host
N:1
Reference Hosts in Listings
Avoid duplication; host info reused/updated




Listings
Reviews
Listing has many Reviews
1:N
Reference Listings  in Reviews
Reviews grow; keeps listing doc lean




Reviews
Reviewers
Review written by one Reviewer
N:1
Reference Reviewers in Reviews
Reviewers write multiple reviews; enables reviewer tracking




Listings
Transactions
Listing has many Transactions
1:N
Reference Listing in Transactions
Time-series data; accessed separately




Listings
Amenities (array)
Listing has many amenities
1:N
Embed Amenities in Listing
Small, static data; needed for listing reads




City (Optional)
Listings
City has many listings
1:N
Both sides
City identified via Listing.Address.market; enables grouping/aggregation




Listings
ReviewScores
Listing has one set of review scores
1:1
Embed Review Scores in Listings
Small, core data;




























3. Patterns Phase¶
    

  1. Recognize common access or structure patterns in data
    2. 

  2. Apply modeling patterns (e.g., bucket, subset, outlier) to optimize for performance, scalability, and simplicity
    3. 























✅ Patterns Phase Table¶






Use Case / Entity
Entity Requirements
Applied Pattern (Allowed)
Why This Pattern?
Context in Project






Host registration: show common Amenities
Read-heavy, rarely changing list of distinct values
Computed Pattern
Precompute into Amenities collection; avoids scans
Q7




Track top reviewers + ReviewCount
Aggregate reviews per reviewer; fast lookup needed
Computed Pattern
Maintain count in Reviewers collection; fast access
Q8




Dynamic review metrics per listing
New score fields added without fixed schema
Attribute Pattern
Store scores as key-value pairs; flexible querying
Q9




Calculate average ReviewsScores
Average multiple, potentially dynamic, score fields
Computed  Pattern
Store scores as key-value; allows fast reading
Q9




Summary of top cities/listings
Repeated aggregated reads across many documents
Computed Pattern
Store precomputed summaries in CitySummary; fast reads
Q11




























Final Schema Design¶
List of All Collections Required¶






Collection Name
Purpose






Listings
Core listing info (title, price, amenities, scores, etc.)




Reviews
Full detailed reviews (referenced from Listings)




Reviewers
Reviewer profiles with computed review count (referenced from Reviews)




Transactions
Kept on the Listings collection the metadata information and included in the Transactions collection the history of the transactions




Hosts
Host information (referenced from Listings)




CitySummary (Optional)
Precomputed metrics for top 10 cities




Amenities (Optional)
List of unique amenities with frequency








Overview¶












































In [244]:






# Drop new collections if they exist to start fresh
db.drop_collection("Listings")
db.drop_collection("Reviews")
db.drop_collection("Reviewers")
db.drop_collection("Transactions")
db.drop_collection("Hosts")





















Out[244]:




{'ok': 1.0}














































Reviews Collection¶


















In [245]:






# Print one example document of 'reviews' array
pprint(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.find_one({"_id": "1022200"}, {"reviews": 1}), sort_dicts=False)

























{'_id': '1022200',
 'reviews': [{'_id': '277195899',
              'date': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 15, 4, 0),
              'listing_id': '1022200',
              'reviewer_id': '710109',
              'reviewer_name': 'Sylvia',
              'comments': 'Great location and lovely facility overall.  A '
                          'great deal!'}]}





















In [246]:






# Step 1: Create Reviews collection
reviews_fields = ["_id", "reviews"]

# Aggregate to extract reviews and their corresponding listing IDs
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    {"$unwind": "$reviews"},                                                        # Unwind the 'reviews' array to create a document for each review
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,                                                                   # Will create a ObjectId for each review
        "Listing_ID": "$_id",                                                       # Include the listing ID
        "Review_ID": "$reviews._id",                                                # Include the review ID
        "Review_Comments": "$reviews.comments",                                     # Include the review comments
        "Review_Date": "$reviews.date",                                             # Include the review date
        "Reviewer_ID": "$reviews.reviewer_id",                                      # Include the reviewer ID
    }},
    # Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/out/
    {"$out": "Reviews"}                                                             # Output directly to 'Reviews' collection in the same database
])





















Out[246]:




<pymongo.synchronous.command_cursor.CommandCursor at 0x2603702c4a0>




















In [247]:






# Step 2: Check the new Reviews collection
print(f"\n\033[1mNumber of documents in 'Reviews' collection:\033[0m {db.Reviews.count_documents({})  }")   # Count the number of documents in the Reviews collection
print(f"\033[1mSample document from 'Reviews' collection:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Reviews.find_one(), sort_dicts=False)                                                             # Print one example document from the Reviews collection

























Number of documents in 'Reviews' collection: 149792
Sample document from 'Reviews' collection:
{'_id': ObjectId('67fea80ca6298d01ad052272'),
 'Listing_ID': '10006546',
 'Review_ID': '58663741',
 'Review_Comments': 'A casa da Ana e do Gonçalo foram o local escolhido para a '
                    'passagem de ano com um grupo de amigos. Fomos super bem '
                    'recebidos com uma grande simpatia e predisposição a '
                    'ajudar com qualquer coisa que fosse necessário.\r\n'
                    'A casa era ainda melhor do que parecia nas fotos, '
                    'totalmente equipada, com mantas, aquecedor e tudo o que '
                    'pudessemos precisar.\r\n'
                    'A localização não podia ser melhor! Não há melhor do que '
                    'acordar de manhã e ao virar da esquina estar a ribeira do '
                    'Porto.',
 'Review_Date': datetime.datetime(2016, 1, 3, 5, 0),
 'Reviewer_ID': '51483096'}



























We applied the Referencing by creating a separate Reviews collection. This addresses the issue of the potentially large and unbounded reviews array embedded within the original listing documents, which negatively impacted performance. We expect smaller, faster-loading listing documents, improved scalability as reviews can grow independently, and efficient querying of reviews using the indexed Listing_ID and Review_ID fields. Each document in this collection represents a single review and links back to its corresponding listing.




















In [248]:






# Step 3: Create Review.Listing_ID and Review.Review_ID indexes for faster queries ("Foreign Key")
db.Reviews.create_index([("Listing_ID")])





















Out[248]:




'Listing_ID_1'

db.Reviews.create_index([("Review_ID")])





















Out[249]:

Reviewers Collection¶


















In [250]:






db.drop_collection("Reviewers")





















Out[250]:




{'ok': 1.0}




















In [251]:






# Step 1: Create Reviewers collection
reviewers_fields = ["_id", "reviews.reviewer_id", "reviews.reviewer_name"]

# Aggregate to extract unique reviewers and their corresponding review IDs
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    {"$unwind": "$reviews"},                                        # Unwind the 'reviews' array to create a document for each review
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$reviews.reviewer_id",                              # Group by reviewer ID
        "Reviewer_Name": {"$first": "$reviews.reviewer_name"},      # Take the first name (assumes consistency)
    }},
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,                                                   # Will create a ObjectId for each reviewer
        "Reviewer_ID": "$_id",                                      # Include reviewer ID
        "Reviewer_Name": 1,                                         # Include reviewer name
        # "Reviews_Count"                                           # Computed Pattern that will be create in Q8
    }},
    # Output directly to 'Reviewers' collection
    {"$out": "Reviewers"}
])





















Out[251]:




<pymongo.synchronous.command_cursor.CommandCursor at 0x2603702f260>




















In [252]:






# Step 2: Check the new Reviewers collection
print(f"\n\033[1mNumber of documents in 'Reviewers' collection:\033[0m {db.Reviewers.count_documents({})}")        # Count the number of documents in the Reviewers collection
print(f"\033[1mSample document from 'Reviewers' collection:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Reviewers.find_one(), sort_dicts=False)                                                                  # Print one example document from the Reviewers collection

























Number of documents in 'Reviewers' collection: 146640
Sample document from 'Reviewers' collection:
{'_id': ObjectId('67fea80ea6298d01ad076b92'),
 'Reviewer_Name': 'Frank',
 'Reviewer_ID': '99803988'}



























We applied Normalization/Referencing by creating a separate Reviewers collection. This addresses the need to efficiently track reviewers and their activity (Q8) without duplicating reviewer names across potentially numerous reviews in the main Reviews collection. Each document in Reviewers represents a unique reviewer, identified by Reviewer_ID. We expect improved data consistency (reviewer names stored once) and efficient lookups for reviewer-specific information, especially when combined with the Reviewer_ID index.




















In [253]:






# Step 3: Create Reviewers.Reviewer_ID and Reviews.Reviewer_ID indexes for faster queries ("Foreign Key")
db.Reviewers.create_index([("Reviewer_ID")])                                        # Create index on Reviewer_ID field in Reviewers collection

Hosts Collection¶


















In [255]:






# Step 1: Create Hosts collection
# Extract all fields with "host_" prefix
host_fields = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    {"$project": {"fields": {"$objectToArray": "$$ROOT"}}},             # Convert document to key-value pairs
    {"$unwind": "$fields"},                                             # Flatten the fields array
    {"$match": {"fields.k": {"$regex": "^host_"}}},                     # Match fields starting with 'host_'
    {"$group": {"_id": "$fields.k"}},                                   # Group by field names to get distinct fields
])

# Convert the aggregation result to a list with only field names
host_fields = sorted([doc["_id"] for doc in host_fields])

# Add "_id" field to host_fields in first position
host_fields.insert(0, "_id")  # Add "_id" field to the beginning of the list

# Print the list of host fields
print(f"Found \033[1m{len(host_fields)} host_* fields\033[0m: \n")
pprint(host_fields)

























Found 17 host_* fields: 

['_id',
 'host_about',
 'host_has_profile_pic',
 'host_id',
 'host_identity_verified',
 'host_is_superhost',
 'host_listings_count',
 'host_location',
 'host_name',
 'host_neighbourhood',
 'host_picture_url',
 'host_response_rate',
 'host_response_time',
 'host_thumbnail_url',
 'host_total_listings_count',
 'host_url',
 'host_verifications']





















In [256]:






# Step 2: Aggregate to extract hosts and their corresponding listing IDs
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    
    # Group documents by host ID to create a document for each host
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$host_id",                                                         # Group by host ID
        "host_fields": {"$first": "$$ROOT"},                                       # Keep the entire document
    }},
    
    # Project the desired fields into the new Hosts collection    
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,                                                                              # Will create a ObjectId for each host
        "Host_ID": "$host_fields.host_id",                                                     # Include the host ID
        "Host_Name": "$host_fields.host_name",                                                 # Include the host name
        "Host_About": "$host_fields.host_about",                                               # Include the host about
        "Host_Location": "$host_fields.host_location",                                         # Include the host location
        "Host_Neighbourhood": "$host_fields.host_neighbourhood",                               # Include the host neighbourhood
        "Host_Picture_URL": "$host_fields.host_picture_url",                                   # Include the host picture URL
        "Host_Thumbnail_URL": "$host_fields.host_thumbnail_url",                               # Include the host thumbnail URL
        "Host_Response_Rate": "$host_fields.host_response_rate",                               # Include the host response rate
        "Host_Response_Time": "$host_fields.host_response_time",                               # Include the host response time
        "Host_Verifications": "$host_fields.host_verifications",                               # Include the host verifications
        "Host_Has_Profile_Pic": "$host_fields.host_has_profile_pic",                           # Include the host has profile pic
        "Host_Identity_Verified": "$host_fields.host_identity_verified",                       # Include the host identity verified
        "Host_Is_Superhost": "$host_fields.host_is_superhost",                                 # Include the host is superhost
        "Host_Listings_Count": "$host_fields.host_listings_count",                             # Include the host listings count
        "Host_Total_Listings_Count": "$host_fields.host_total_listings_count",                 # Include the host total listings count
        "Host_URL": "$host_fields.host_url",                                                   # Include the host URL
    }},   
    # Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/out/
    {"$out": "Hosts"}                                                             # Output directly to 'Hosts' collection in the same database
])





















Out[256]:




<pymongo.synchronous.command_cursor.CommandCursor at 0x2603cc92090>




















In [257]:






# Step 3: Check the new Hosts collection
print(f"\n\033[1mNumber of documents in 'Hosts' collection:\033[0m {db.Hosts.count_documents({})}")  # Count the number of documents in the Hosts collection
print(f"\033[1mSample document from 'Hosts' collection:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Hosts.find_one(), sort_dicts=False)                                                        # Print one example document from the Hosts collection

























Number of documents in 'Hosts' collection: 5104
Sample document from 'Hosts' collection:
{'_id': ObjectId('67fea811a6298d01ad09a862'),
 'Host_ID': '10002884',
 'Host_Name': 'Han',
 'Host_About': 'Welcome to my room!',
 'Host_Location': 'HK',
 'Host_Neighbourhood': 'Mong Kok',
 'Host_Picture_URL': 'https://a0.muscache.com/im/users/10002884/profile_pic/1387359746/original.jpg?aki_policy=profile_x_medium',
 'Host_Thumbnail_URL': 'https://a0.muscache.com/im/users/10002884/profile_pic/1387359746/original.jpg?aki_policy=profile_small',
 'Host_Response_Rate': 100,
 'Host_Response_Time': 'within an hour',
 'Host_Verifications': ['email', 'phone', 'reviews', 'jumio', 'government_id'],
 'Host_Has_Profile_Pic': True,
 'Host_Identity_Verified': True,
 'Host_Is_Superhost': False,
 'Host_Listings_Count': 1,
 'Host_Total_Listings_Count': 1,
 'Host_URL': 'https://www.airbnb.com/users/show/10002884'}



























We applied Data Normalization/Reference by creating a separate Hosts collection. This eliminates the duplication of host information previously embedded in each listing document. Each document in Hosts represents a unique host, identified by Host_ID, and is referenced from the Listings collection. We expect improved data integrity (updates to host info only need to happen in one place), reduced overall storage, and efficient querying of host-specific information using the indexed Host_ID.




















In [258]:






# Step 3.1: Check if all host IDs are unique
host_ids = db.Hosts.aggregate([
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Host_ID",
        "count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    {"$match": {
        "count": {"$gt": 1}
    }}
])
duplicates = list(host_ids)
if duplicates:
    print(f"Warning: Found {len(duplicates)} duplicate host IDs.")
    for doc in duplicates:
        print(f"Host ID: {doc['_id']} appears {doc['count']} times.")
else:
    print("All host IDs are unique.")

























All host IDs are unique.





















In [259]:






# Step 4: Create Hosts.Host_ID index for faster queries ("Foreign Key")
db.Hosts.create_index([("Host_ID")])  # Create index on Host_ID field

'Host_ID_1'

In [261]:






# Step 1: Create Transactions collection
transactions_fields = ["_id", 
                       # "transactions.bucket_end_date", "transactions.bucket_start_date", "transactions.transaction_count", 
                       "transactions.transactions"]





















In [262]:






# Aggregate to extract transactions and their corresponding listing IDs
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    {"$match": {"transactions.transactions": {"$exists": True}}},                        # Match documents where 'transactions.transactions' exists
    {"$unwind": "$transactions.transactions"},                                           # Unwind the 'transactions' array to create a document for each transaction
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,                                                                        # Will create a ObjectId for each transaction
        "Listing_ID": "$_id",                                                            # Include the listing ID
        "Transaction_ID": "$transactions.transactions._id",                              # Include the transaction ID
        "Transaction_Date": "$transactions.transactions.date",                           # Include the transaction date
        "Transaction_Price": "$transactions.transactions.price"                          # Include the transaction price
    }},
    # Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/out/
    {"$out": "Transactions"}                                                             # Output directly to 'Transactions' collection in the same database
])





















Out[262]:




<pymongo.synchronous.command_cursor.CommandCursor at 0x2603ddda690>




















In [263]:






# Step 2: Check the new Transactions collection
print(f"\n\033[1mNumber of documents in 'Transactions' collection:\033[0m {db.Transactions.count_documents({})}") # Count the number of documents in the Transactions collection
print(f"\033[1mSample document from 'Transactions' collection:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Transactions.find_one(), sort_dicts=False)                                                              # Print one example document from the Transactions collection

























Number of documents in 'Transactions' collection: 311093
Sample document from 'Transactions' collection:
{'_id': ObjectId('67fea811a6298d01ad09bc52'),
 'Listing_ID': '10006546',
 'Transaction_Date': datetime.datetime(2008, 8, 12, 0, 0),
 'Transaction_Price': Decimal128('132.1063781684291313922585686668753')}



























We applied Referencing by creating a separate Transactions collection, moving the potentially large and time-sensitive transactions.transactions array out of the main listing document. This isolates transaction data for focused querying (like in Q10). Each document represents a single transaction and includes a Listing_ID reference. We expect faster reads for the main Listings collection, improved performance for time-based queries on transactions (especially with the index on Listing_ID and potentially Transaction_Date), and better scalability for transaction data (as it can grow independently of the listing document and we have limit of 16MB per document).




Note: We decided to keep the transactions.bucket_end_date, transactions.bucket_start_date, and transactions.transaction_count fields within the main Listings collection (under the Transactions subdocument, but without the nested transactions array). These fields provide a useful summary about the transaction history associated with the listing, which might be needed for display without querying the full Transactions collection.


















In [264]:






# Step 2.1: Check if all (Listing_ID, Transaction_Date, Transaction_Price) pairs are unique
transactions_ids = db.Transactions.aggregate([
    {"$group": {
        "_id": {"Listing_ID": "$Listing_ID", "Transaction_Date": "$Transaction_Date", "Transaction_Price": "$Transaction_Price"},
        "count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    {"$match": {
        "count": {"$gt": 1}
    }}
])
duplicates = list(transactions_ids)
if duplicates:
    print(f"Warning: Found {len(duplicates)} duplicate (Listing_ID, Transaction_Date, Transaction_Price) pairs.")
    for doc in duplicates:
        print(f"Pair: {doc['_id']} appears {doc['count']} times.")
else:
    print("All (Listing_ID, Transaction_Date, Transaction_Price) pairs are unique.")

























All (Listing_ID, Transaction_Date, Transaction_Price) pairs are unique.





















In [265]:






# Step 3: Create Transactions.Listing_ID index for faster queries ("Foreign Key")
db.Transactions.create_index([("Listing_ID")])  # Create index on Listing_ID field





















Out[265]:




'Listing_ID_1'
























Listings Collection¶


















In [266]:






db.drop_collection("Listings")





















Out[266]:




{'ok': 1.0}




















In [267]:






# Step 1: Create Listings collection
# Extract all fields except for "reviews", "transactions.transactions" array, and "host_" fields
listings_fields = db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    {"$project": {"fields": {"$objectToArray": "$$ROOT"}}},             # Convert document to key-value pairs
    {"$unwind": "$fields"},                                             # Flatten the fields array
    {"$match": {
        "fields.k": {
            "$not": {
                "$regex": "^reviews|^transactions\\.transactions|^host_"
            }
        }
    }},
    {"$group": {"_id": "$fields.k"}}                                    # Group by field names to get distinct fields
])

# Convert the aggregation result to a list with only field names
listings_fields = sorted([doc["_id"] for doc in listings_fields])

# Print the list of listings fields
print(f"Found \033[1m{len(listings_fields)} listings fields\033[0m: \n")
pprint(listings_fields)

























Found 45 listings fields: 

['_id',
 'access',
 'accommodates',
 'address',
 'amenities',
 'availability',
 'bathrooms',
 'bed_type',
 'bedrooms',
 'beds',
 'calendar_last_scraped',
 'cancellation_policy',
 'cleaning_fee',
 'description',
 'extra_people',
 'first_review',
 'guests_included',
 'house_rules',
 'images',
 'interaction',
 'last_review',
 'last_scraped',
 'listing_url',
 'maximum_nights',
 'minimum_nights',
 'monthly_price',
 'name',
 'neighborhood_overview',
 'notes',
 'number_of_reviews',
 'price',
 'property_type',
 'review_scores_checkin',
 'review_scores_cleanliness',
 'review_scores_communication',
 'review_scores_location',
 'review_scores_rating',
 'review_scores_value',
 'room_type',
 'security_deposit',
 'space',
 'summary',
 'transactions',
 'transit',
 'weekly_price']





















In [268]:






# Step 2: Aggregate to extract listings and their corresponding listing IDs
db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate([
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,                                                                   # Will create a ObjectId for each listing
        "Listing_ID": "$_id",                                                       # Include the listing ID
        "Host_ID": "$host_id",                                                      # Include the host ID
        "Name": "$name",                                                            # Name of the listing
        "Description": "$description",                                              # Description of the listing
        "Summary": "$summary",                                                      # Summary of the listing
        "Space": "$space",                                                          # Space details
        "Property_Type": "$property_type",                                          # Type of property
        "Room_Type": "$room_type",                                                  # Type of room
        "Accommodates": "$accommodates",                                            # Number of guests accommodated
        "Bedrooms": "$bedrooms",                                                    # Number of bedrooms
        "Beds": "$beds",                                                            # Number of beds
        "Bathrooms": "$bathrooms",                                                  # Number of bathrooms
        "Bed_Type": "$bed_type",                                                    # Type of bed
        "Price": "$price",                                                          # Price per night
        "Cleaning_Fee": "$cleaning_fee",                                            # Cleaning fee
        "Security_Deposit": "$security_deposit",                                    # Security deposit
        "Extra_People": "$extra_people",                                            # Extra charges for additional people
        "Weekly_Price": "$weekly_price",                                            # Weekly price
        "Monthly_Price": "$monthly_price",                                          # Monthly price
        "Minimum_Nights": "$minimum_nights",                                        # Minimum nights for booking
        "Maximum_Nights": "$maximum_nights",                                        # Maximum nights for booking
        "Guests_Included": "$guests_included",                                      # Number of guests included in the price
        "Address": "$address",                                                      # Address details
        "Access": "$access",                                                        # Access details
        "Interaction": "$interaction",                                              # Interaction details
        "House_Rules": "$house_rules",                                              # House rules
        "Amenities": "$amenities",                                                  # Amenities provided
        "Availability": "$availability",                                            # Availability details
        "Calendar_Last_Scraped": "$calendar_last_scraped",                          # Last scraped date of the calendar
        "Last_Scraped": "$last_scraped",                                            # Last scraped date of the listing
        "Cancellation_Policy": "$cancellation_policy",                              # Cancellation policy
        "Neighborhood_Overview": "$neighborhood_overview",                          # Overview of the neighborhood
        "Transit": "$transit",                                                      # Transit information
        "Notes": "$notes",                                                          # Additional notes
        "Images": "$images",                                                        # Images of the listing
        "Listing_URL": "$listing_url",                                              # URL of the listing
        "First_Review": "$first_review",                                            # Date of the first review
        "Last_Review": "$last_review",                                              # Date of the last review
        "Number_of_Reviews": "$number_of_reviews",                                  # Total number of reviews
        "Review_Scores_Rating": "$review_scores_rating",                            # Review scores rating
        
        # Review scores for subdocument | Capitalize and prefix the score name (e.g., "review_scores__checkin" -> "Checkin")
        "Review_Scores": {
            "Checkin": "$review_scores_checkin",                                    # Check-in rating
            "Cleanliness": "$review_scores_cleanliness",                            # Cleanliness rating
            "Communication": "$review_scores_communication",                        # Communication rating
            "Location": "$review_scores_location",                                  # Location rating
            "Rating": "$review_scores_rating",                                      # Overall rating
            "Value": "$review_scores_value"                                         # Value rating
        },
        
        "Transactions": "$transactions"                                             # Transactions details
    }},
    # Drop the 'transactions.transactions' field from the listings collection
    {"$unset": "Transactions.transactions"},
    
    # Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/out/
    {"$out": "Listings"}                                                            # Output directly to 'Listings' collection in the same database
])





















Out[268]:




<pymongo.synchronous.command_cursor.CommandCursor at 0x2603ddda720>




















In [269]:






# Step 3: Check the new Listings collection
print(f"\n\033[1mNumber of documents in 'Listings' collection:\033[0m {db.Listings.count_documents({})}")     # Count the number of documents in the Listings collection
print(f"\033[1mSample document from 'Listings' collection:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Listings.find_one(), sort_dicts=False)                                                               # Print one example document from the Listings collection
