                  'bucket_start_date': datetime.datetime(1979, 10, 4, 0, 0),
                  'transaction_count': 21}}



























We applied schema restructuring to create the final Listings collection. This involved removing embedded host details, the full reviews array, and the detailed transactions array, replacing them with references (Host_ID). We restructured the review_scores_* fields into a Review_Scores subdocument, applying the Attribute Pattern for flexibility (Q9). Key identifying information (Listing_ID), frequently accessed data (Name, Price, Address, Amenities, etc.), and summary transaction info remain embedded. We expect significantly faster retrieval of core listing information for the primary customer-facing use case (Q1), as documents are much smaller. The restructured Review_Scores allows for flexible querying of score averages.




















In [270]:






# Step 3.1: Check if all listing IDs are unique
listings_ids = db.Listings.aggregate([
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Listing_ID",
        "count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    {"$match": {
        "count": {"$gt": 1}
    }}
])
duplicates = list(listings_ids)
if duplicates:
    print(f"Warning: Found {len(duplicates)} duplicate listing IDs.")
    for doc in duplicates:
        print(f"Listing ID: {doc['_id']} appears {doc['count']} times.")
else:
    print("All listing IDs are unique.")

























All listing IDs are unique.





















In [271]:






# Step 4: Create Listings.Listing_ID and Listings.Host_ID indexes for faster queries ("Foreign Key")
db.Listings.create_index([("Listing_ID")])                                      # Create index on Listing_ID field





















Out[271]:




'Listing_ID_1'




















In [272]:






db.Listings.create_index([("Host_ID")])                                         # Create index on Host_ID field





















Out[272]:




'Host_ID_1'














































🔍 Queries¶






















🛋️Standard Difficulty Questions [2 points per question]¶






















Question 2¶






















Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [273]:






# 2)	Once a month, we reward hosts with recognition. 
#       Select three superhosts with at least two listings that can accommodate more than four people.





















In [274]:






# Start the timer
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Filter for superhosts and listings accommodating > 4
    {"$match": {"host_is_superhost": True, "accommodates": {"$gt": 4}}},
    # Group by host_id to count listings and collect accommodates values
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$host_id",
        "HostName": {"$first": "$host_name"},
        "ListingCount": {"$sum": 1},
        "AccommodatesList": {"$push": "$accommodates"}  # Collect all accommodates values
    }},
    # Filter for hosts with at least 2 listings
    {"$match": {"ListingCount": {"$gte": 2}}},
    # Sort by host name for consistency
    {"$sort": {"HostName": 1}},
    
    # Limit to 3 superhosts
    # {"$limit": 3},
    
    # Project output without _id
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "HostName": 1,
        "ListingCount": 1,
        "AccommodatesList": 1                           # Include the list of accommodation capacities
    }}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nFound \033[1m{len(result)} superhosts\033[0m with at least 2 listings that can accommodate more than 4 people.\n")
for host in result:
    print(f"\033[1mHost Name\033[0m: {host['HostName']:<25} | \033[1mListing Count:\033[0m {host['ListingCount']} | \033[1mAccommodates List:\033[0m {host['AccommodatesList']}")

























Execution time: 0.0209 seconds

Found 14 superhosts with at least 2 listings that can accommodate more than 4 people.

Host Name: Aj                        | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [16, 16]
Host Name: Aline                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 12]
Host Name: Assunção De Fatima        | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 8]
Host Name: Daniel                    | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 16]
Host Name: Elite                     | Listing Count: 3 | Accommodates List: [14, 6, 6]
Host Name: Great Vacation Retreats   | Listing Count: 3 | Accommodates List: [5, 6, 6]
Host Name: Jane                      | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [6, 9]
Host Name: Liiiving                  | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [6, 8]
Host Name: Miguel & João             | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 5]
Host Name: Mindy                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [6, 6]
Host Name: Patty And Beckett         | Listing Count: 3 | Accommodates List: [8, 8, 8]
Host Name: Resortica                 | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [8, 8]
Host Name: Wilson&Shan               | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [9, 8]
Host Name: Yaiza                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [8, 6]

























Query with New Schema¶


















In [275]:






start_time = time.time()
query2 = list(db.Hosts.aggregate([
    
    # Start with Hosts collection to filter superhosts
    {"$match": {"Host_Is_Superhost": True}},
    
    # Lookup listings for each host
    {"$lookup": {
        "from": "Listings",
        "localField": "Host_ID",
        "foreignField": "Host_ID",
        "as": "listings"
    }},
    
    # Filter listings accommodating > 4
    {"$project": {
        "HostName": "$Host_Name",
        "listings": {
            "$filter": {
                "input": "$listings",
                "cond": {"$gt": ["$$this.Accommodates", 4]}
            }
        }
    }},
    
    # Group to count listings per host
    {"$project": {
        "HostName": 1,
        "ListingCount": {"$size": "$listings"},
        "AccommodatesList": "$listings.Accommodates"
    }},
    
    # Filter hosts with at least 2 listings
    {"$match": {"ListingCount": {"$gte": 2}}},
    
    # Sort by name for consistency
    {"$sort": {"HostName": 1}}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nFound \033[1m{len(query2)} superhosts\033[0m with at least 2 listings accommodating > 4 people.\n")
for host in query2:
    print(f"\033[1mHost Name\033[0m: {host['HostName']:<25} | \033[1mListing Count:\033[0m {host['ListingCount']} | \033[1mAccommodates List:\033[0m {host['AccommodatesList']}")

























Execution time: 0.0379 seconds

Found 14 superhosts with at least 2 listings accommodating > 4 people.

Host Name: Aj                        | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [16, 16]
Host Name: Aline                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 12]
Host Name: Assunção De Fatima        | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 8]
Host Name: Daniel                    | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 16]
Host Name: Elite                     | Listing Count: 3 | Accommodates List: [14, 6, 6]
Host Name: Great Vacation Retreats   | Listing Count: 3 | Accommodates List: [5, 6, 6]
Host Name: Jane                      | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [6, 9]
Host Name: Liiiving                  | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [6, 8]
Host Name: Miguel & João             | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 5]
Host Name: Mindy                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [6, 6]
Host Name: Patty And Beckett         | Listing Count: 3 | Accommodates List: [8, 8, 8]
Host Name: Resortica                 | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [8, 8]
Host Name: Wilson&Shan               | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [9, 8]
Host Name: Yaiza                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [8, 6]





















In [276]:






# Select three superhosts with at least two listings that can accommodate more than four people
for host in query2[:3]:
    print(f"\033[1mHost Name\033[0m: {host['HostName']:<25} | \033[1mListing Count:\033[0m {host['ListingCount']} | \033[1mAccommodates List:\033[0m {host['AccommodatesList']}")

























Host Name: Aj                        | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [16, 16]
Host Name: Aline                     | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 12]
Host Name: Assunção De Fatima        | Listing Count: 2 | Accommodates List: [5, 8]



























Comparison (Q2): The new schema query uses a $lookup to join Hosts and Listings. While lookups can introduce overhead compared to querying a single collection, this approach maintains normalized data by avoiding host information duplication. The execution time in the new schema (0.038s) is slightly slower than the original (0.021s) for this specific query. This is expected due to the left outer join operation ($lookup). However, the trade-off ensures data integrity and avoids redundancy across the dataset.




Note: The Top 3 superhosts presented were selected based on alphabetical order of the host names.












































Question 3¶


















In [277]:






# 3)	The company considers investing into property to rent. 
#       Which bed type is most common in listings with a waterfront and a dishwasher in New York?

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [278]:






# 3. Most common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Filter for New York, waterfront, and dishwasher (case-insensitive)
    {"$match": {
        "address.market": "New York",
        "amenities": {
            "$elemMatch": {"$regex": "waterfront", "$options": "i"}  # Matches any waterfront variant (case-insensitive)
        },
        "amenities": {
            "$elemMatch": {"$regex": "dishwasher", "$options": "i"}  # Matches any dishwasher variant (case-insensitive)
        }
    }},
    
    # Group by bed_type and count occurrences
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$bed_type",
        "Count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    
    # Sort by count descending
    {"$sort": {"Count": -1}},
    
    # Limit to 1 (most common)
    {"$limit": 1},
    
    # Project output
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "BedType": "$_id",
        "Count": 1
    }}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nMost common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher is \033[1m{result[0]['BedType']}\033[0m with \033[1m{result[0]['Count']}\033[0m occurrences.")

























Execution time: 0.0497 seconds

Most common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher is Real Bed with 75 occurrences.

























Query with New Schema¶


















In [279]:






start_time = time.time()

query3 = list(db.Listings.aggregate([
    
    # Filter for New York, waterfront, and dishwasher (case-insensitive)
    {"$match": {
        "Address.market": "New York",
        "Amenities": {"$elemMatch": {"$regex": "waterfront", "$options": "i"}},  # Matches any waterfront variant (case-insensitive)
        "Amenities": {"$elemMatch": {"$regex": "dishwasher", "$options": "i"}},  # Matches any dishwasher variant (case-insensitive)
        "Bed_Type": {"$exists": True}                                            # Ensure Bed_Type field exists
    }},
    
    # Group by bed_type and count occurrences
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Bed_Type",
        "Count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    
    # Sort by count descending
    {"$sort": {"Count": -1}},
    
    # Limit to 1 (most common)
    {"$limit": 1},
    
    # Project output
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "BedType": "$_id",
        "Count": 1
    }}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nMost common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher is \033[1m{query3[0]['BedType']}\033[0m with \033[1m{query3[0]['Count']}\033[0m occurrences.")

























Execution time: 0.0410 seconds

Most common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher is Real Bed with 75 occurrences.



























Comparison (Q3): Both queries yield the same result ("Real Bed", count 75). The new schema query targets the optimized Listings collection. Performance is comparable (0.041s vs 0.050s in the original). This indicates that querying the leaner Listings collection, even with similar filtering logic on embedded arrays (Amenities), maintains performance while offering better overall structure. After adding indexes, the new schema query becomes faster (0.027s). Indexing Address.market and Amenities provides a clear benefit for this query pattern.




















In [280]:






# Indexing 'Address.market' and 'Amenities' fields for faster queries (Single Field Indexes - Text)
db.Listings.create_index([("Address.market")])  # Create index on Address.market field
db.Listings.create_index([("Amenities")])       # Create index on Amenities field





















Out[280]:




'Amenities_1'




















In [281]:






# Re-run the query with indexes
start_time = time.time()

query3 = list(db.Listings.aggregate([
    
    # Filter for New York, waterfront, and dishwasher (case-insensitive)
    {"$match": {
        "Address.market": "New York",
        "Amenities": {"$elemMatch": {"$regex": "waterfront", "$options": "i"}},  # Matches any waterfront variant (case-insensitive)
        "Amenities": {"$elemMatch": {"$regex": "dishwasher", "$options": "i"}},  # Matches any dishwasher variant (case-insensitive)
        "Bed_Type": {"$exists": True}                                            # Ensure Bed_Type field exists
    }},
    
    # Group by bed_type and count occurrences
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Bed_Type",
        "Count": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    
    # Sort by count descending
    {"$sort": {"Count": -1}},
    
    # Limit to 1 (most common)
    {"$limit": 1},
    
    # Project output
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "BedType": "$_id",
        "Count": 1
    }}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nMost common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher is \033[1m{query3[0]['BedType']}\033[0m with \033[1m{query3[0]['Count']}\033[0m occurrences.")

























Execution time: 0.0268 seconds

Most common bed type in New York listings with waterfront and dishwasher is Real Bed with 75 occurrences.

























    

  • As we expected, the new schema query with indexing on Address.market and Amenities is faster than the original query, because in this case we are searching for a specific value in the Amenities array and Address.market field.
    • 













































Question 4¶


















In [282]:






# 4)	We're considering hiring someone to write reviews professionally. 
#       Who wrote the longest review in New York?

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [283]:






# 4. Reviewer who wrote the longest review in New York
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Filter for New York
    {"$match": {"address.market": "New York"}},
    # Unwind reviews array
    {"$unwind": "$reviews"},
    # Project review length and reviewer, handling null comments
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "ReviewerName": "$reviews.reviewer_name",
        "ReviewLength": {"$strLenCP":                # Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/strLenCP/
            {"$ifNull": ["$reviews.comments", ""]}}  # Default to empty string if null
    }},
    # Sort by length descending
    {"$sort": {"ReviewLength": -1}},
    # Limit to 1
    {"$limit": 1}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline)) # [{'ReviewLength': 4665, 'ReviewerName': 'Angela'}]
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nReviewer who wrote the longest review in New York is: \033[1m{result[0]['ReviewerName']}\033[0m with \033[1m{result[0]['ReviewLength']} characters\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0690 seconds

Reviewer who wrote the longest review in New York is: Angela with 4665 characters

























Query with New Schema¶


















In [284]:






start_time = time.time()

query4 = list(db.Reviews.aggregate([
    # Join Reviews with Listings to filter by New York
    {"$lookup": {
        "from": "Listings",
        "localField": "Listing_ID",
        "foreignField": "Listing_ID",
        "as": "listing"
    }},
    
    # Unwind the listings array to create a document for each review
    {"$unwind": "$listing"},
    
    # Filter for New York listings
    {"$match": {"listing.Address.market": "New York"}},
    
    # Project review length and reviewer, handling null comments
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "Reviewer_ID": "$Reviewer_ID",                                          # Include Reviewer_ID
        "ReviewLength": {"$strLenCP": {"$ifNull": ["$Review_Comments", ""]}}    # Calculate length of review comments (handling nulls)
    }},
    
    # Join Reviews with Reviewers to get reviewer names
    {"$lookup": {
        "from": "Reviewers",
        "localField": "Reviewer_ID",
        "foreignField": "Reviewer_ID",
        "as": "reviewer"
    }},
    
    # Unwind the reviewers array to create a document for each review
    {"$unwind": "$reviewer"},
    
    # Project reviewer name
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "ReviewerName": "$reviewer.Reviewer_Name",
        "ReviewLength": 1
    }},
    
    # Sort by length descending
    {"$sort": {"ReviewLength": -1}},
    
    # Limit to 1 (reviewer with longest review)
    {"$limit": 1}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# pprint(query4)
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
pprint(query4, sort_dicts=False)
print(f"\nReviewer who wrote the longest review in New York is: \033[1m{query4[0]['ReviewerName']}\033[0m with \033[1m{query4[0]['ReviewLength']} characters\033[0m")

























Execution time: 14.0446 seconds
[{'ReviewLength': 4665, 'ReviewerName': 'Angela'}]

Reviewer who wrote the longest review in New York is: Angela with 4665 characters



























Comparison (Q4): The new schema query involves lookups between Reviews, Listings (for the market filter), and Reviewers. Although separating collections often improves performance for targeted reads, the multiple $lookup stages required here introduce significant overhead compared to the original query which only needed to unwind the embedded reviews array. This resulted in a considerably longer execution time (14.04s vs 0.069s). While indexing helps, the cost of joining large collections for this specific aggregation outweighs the benefit of smaller individual documents in the Reviews collection.






If this query was part of the queries list to consider for optimization (not part of queries to "consider for database optimization" - Q7 to Q11),  further optimization (like denormalizing the reviewer name into the Reviews collection - Extended Reference Pattern) might be considered in a real-world scenario. However, the current schema prioritises scalability and avoids data duplication.














































Question 5¶


















In [285]:






# 5)	To assess the security of different areas, what is the biggest and smallest (price-security deposit) difference per number of visitors at a property?

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [286]:






# 5. Biggest and smallest (price - security deposit) difference per number of visitors
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Filter for listings with price and security deposit
    {"$match": {
        "price": {"$exists": True, "$ne": None},                                  # Price exists and is not null
        "security_deposit": {"$exists": True, "$ne": None}                        # Security deposit exists and is not null
    }},
    
    # Calculate difference per visitor, converting strings to numbers
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "DifferencePerVisitor": {
            "$divide": [
                {"$abs":                                                        # Absolute value of difference
                    {"$subtract": [
                        {"$toDouble": {"$ifNull": ["$price", "0"]}},            # Convert price to double, default 0
                        {"$toDouble": {"$ifNull": ["$security_deposit", "0"]}}  # Convert security_deposit, default 0
                    ]}
                }
                , "$accommodates"
            ]
        }
    }},
    # Group to find min and max
    {"$group": {
        "_id": None,
        "MaxDifference": {"$max": "$DifferencePerVisitor"},
        "MinDifference": {"$min": "$DifferencePerVisitor"}
    }},
    # Project output with rounding
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "MaxDifference": {"$round": ["$MaxDifference", 2]},
        "MinDifference": {"$round": ["$MinDifference", 2]}
    }}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nBiggest difference (price - security deposit) per number of visitors: \033[1m{result[0]['MaxDifference']}\033[0m")
print(f"Smallest difference (price - security deposit) per number of visitors: \033[1m{result[0]['MinDifference']}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0317 seconds

Biggest difference (price - security deposit) per number of visitors: 19229.5
Smallest difference (price - security deposit) per number of visitors: 0.0

























Query with New Schema¶


















In [287]:






start_time = time.time()

query5 = list(db.Listings.aggregate([
    # Filter for listings with security deposit and accommodates fields
    {"$match": {
        "Security_Deposit": {"$exists": True},             # Security deposit exists
        "Accommodates": {"$exists": True}                  # Accommodates field exists
    }},
            
    # Calculate difference per visitor, converting strings to numbers
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "DifferencePerVisitor": {
            "$divide": [
                {"$abs": {"$subtract": [
                    {"$toDouble": "$Price"},
                    {"$toDouble": {"$ifNull": ["$Security_Deposit", "0"]}}
                ]}},
                "$Accommodates"
            ]
        }
    }},
    
    # Group to find min and max
    {"$group": {
        "_id": None,
        "MaxDifference": {"$max": "$DifferencePerVisitor"},
        "MinDifference": {"$min": "$DifferencePerVisitor"}
    }},
    
    # Project output with rounding
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "MaxDifference": {"$round": ["$MaxDifference", 2]},
        "MinDifference": {"$round": ["$MinDifference", 2]}
    }}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nBiggest difference (price - security deposit) per visitor: \033[1m{query5[0]['MaxDifference']}\033[0m")
print(f"Smallest difference (price - security deposit) per visitor: \033[1m{query5[0]['MinDifference']}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0210 seconds

Biggest difference (price - security deposit) per visitor: 19229.5
Smallest difference (price - security deposit) per visitor: 0.0

























Note: This query assumes both price and security_deposit exist and are valid numbers for the calculation. The $match stage ensures we only consider documents where these fields are present and not null. The $ifNull and type conversion steps handle potential data inconsistencies found during cleanup.




Comparison (Q5): Both queries correctly identify the min/max difference per visitor (Min: 0.0, Max: 19229.5). The new schema query operates on the Listings collection where Price and Security_Deposit are already correctly typed, simplifying the $project stage compared to the original query. The execution time is notably faster in the new schema (0.021s vs 0.032s original), likely due to processing leaner documents and avoiding conversions within the pipeline.














































Question 6¶


















In [288]:






# 6)  Identify areas by whether they are typically used for short breaks, like weekend mini breaks, or whether they are more suitable for long trips. 
#     This information support targeted advertising of different customer types. 
#     It is not expected to change much over time so we won’t look to update it, we just require current view. 
#     What is the average duration of stay (in nights) per type of property per city (you can use the maximum_nights to measure length of stays)? 
#     For each property type return the city with the highest and lowest average value.

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [289]:






# 6. Average stay duration per property type per city, with highest and lowest
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Group by property type and city, converting maximum_nights to number
    {"$group": {
        "_id": {"PropertyType": "$property_type", "City": "$address.market"},
        "AvgMaxNights": {"$avg": {"$toInt": {"$ifNull": ["$maximum_nights", "0"]}}}  # Convert to int, default 0
    }},
    # Group by property type to find min/max cities
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$_id.PropertyType",
        "Cities": {
            "$push": {
                # Handle with Null values
                "City": {"$ifNull": ["$_id.City", "Unknown"]},                      # Default to "Unknown" if null
                "AvgMaxNights": "$AvgMaxNights"}
        }
    }},
    # Sort cities by AvgMaxNights
    {"$sort": {"Cities.AvgMaxNights": 1}},
    
    # Project min and max per property type
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "PropertyType": "$_id",
        "HighestAvgCity": {
            "$arrayElemAt": [
                "$Cities",
                {"$indexOfArray": ["$Cities.AvgMaxNights", {"$max": "$Cities.AvgMaxNights"}]}
            ]
        },
        "LowestAvgCity": {
            "$arrayElemAt": [
                "$Cities",
                {"$indexOfArray": ["$Cities.AvgMaxNights", {"$min": "$Cities.AvgMaxNights"}]}
            ]
        }
    }}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nAverage stay duration per property type per city:\n")
print(f"{'\033[1mProperty Type\033[0m':<30} | {'\033[1mHighest Avg City\033[0m':<40} | {'\033[1mLowest Avg City\033[0m':<25}")
print("=" * 80)
for item in result:
    print(f"{item['PropertyType']:<22} | {item['HighestAvgCity']['City']:<32} | {item['LowestAvgCity']['City']:<20}")
    print(f"                         \033[1mHighest Avg Nights:\033[0m {round(item['HighestAvgCity']['AvgMaxNights']):<12}   \033[1mLowest Avg Nights:\033[0m {round(item['LowestAvgCity']['AvgMaxNights']):<5}")
    print("-" * 80)

























Execution time: 0.0547 seconds

Query with New Schema¶


















In [290]:






start_time = time.time()

query6 = list(db.Listings.aggregate([
    # Group by property type and city, converting maximum_nights to number
     {"$group": {
        "_id": {"PropertyType": "$Property_Type", "City": "$Address.market"},
        "AvgMaxNights": {"$avg": {"$toInt": {"$ifNull": ["$Maximum_Nights", "0"]}}}
    }},
    # Group by property type to find min/max cities
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$_id.PropertyType",
        "Cities": {"$push": {
            "City": {"$ifNull": ["$_id.City", "Unknown"]},
            "AvgMaxNights": "$AvgMaxNights"
        }}
    }},
    
    # Sort cities by AvgMaxNights
    {"$sort": {"Cities.AvgMaxNights": 1}},
        
    # Project min and max per property type
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "PropertyType": "$_id",
        "HighestAvgCity": {"$arrayElemAt": [
            "$Cities",
            {"$indexOfArray": ["$Cities.AvgMaxNights", {"$max": "$Cities.AvgMaxNights"}]}
        ]},
        "LowestAvgCity": {"$arrayElemAt": [
            "$Cities",
            {"$indexOfArray": ["$Cities.AvgMaxNights", {"$min": "$Cities.AvgMaxNights"}]}
        ]}
    }}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nAverage stay duration per property type per city:\n")
print(f"{'\033[1mProperty Type\033[0m':<30} | {'\033[1mHighest Avg City\033[0m':<40} | {'\033[1mLowest Avg City\033[0m':<25}")
print("=" * 80)
for item in query6:
    print(f"{item['PropertyType']:<22} | {item['HighestAvgCity']['City']:<32} | {item['LowestAvgCity']['City']:<20}")
    print(f"                         \033[1mHighest Avg Nights:\033[0m {round(item['HighestAvgCity']['AvgMaxNights']):<12}   \033[1mLowest Avg Nights:\033[0m {round(item['LowestAvgCity']['AvgMaxNights']):<5}")
    print("-" * 80)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Note on Outliers: The results show a very high maximum average ($5\;200\;438$ nights for Apartments in Istanbul). This is likely due to outlier values in the maximum_nights field (like $2\;147\;483\;647$) skewing the average significantly.


In a real-world scenario, these outliers should be investigated and potentially cleaned or filtered out before calculating the average, or a more robust metric like the median might be preferred to better represent typical stay lengths. However, following the prompt's instruction to use maximum_nights and calculate the average, we present the result as calculated.
























Comparison (Q6): The logic is identical, just adapted to the new field names (Property_Type, Address.market, Maximum_Nights) in the Listings collection. Performance is slightly better in the new schema (0.048s vs 0.055s). This improvement is likely due to operating on the leaner Listings collection, even though the aggregation logic remains complex involving grouping and sorting potentially large intermediate arrays.














































⏳Advanced Difficulty Questions [3 points per question]¶
(Consider database optimization for these queries)






















Question 7¶


















In [291]:






# 7)	We are creating a new webpage for hosts when setting up their account. 
#       It will list suggested typical amenities. 
#       This data will need to be available every time a host registers a property but is not expected to change very much. 
#       The starting point for the list will be all unique amenities currently listed in properties (across all documents). 
#       Optimize the database for this use case and show how the data should be queried.

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [292]:






# 7. All unique amenities across listings
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Unwind amenities array
    {"$unwind": "$amenities"},
    # Group to get unique amenities
    {"$group": {"_id": "$amenities"}},
    # Project output
    {"$project": {"_id": 0, "Amenity": "$_id"}},
    # Sort alphabetically
    {"$sort": {"Amenity": 1}}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds\n")
pprint(result[:5])                                              # Display first few unique amenities
print(f"\n\33[1mTotal unique amenities:\33[0m {len(result)}")

























Execution time: 0.1049 seconds

[{'Amenity': '24-hour check-in'},
 {'Amenity': 'Accessible-height bed'},
 {'Amenity': 'Accessible-height toilet'},
 {'Amenity': 'Air conditioning'},
 {'Amenity': 'Air purifier'}]

Total unique amenities: 185

























Query with New Schema¶






















Optimization for Q7: Computed Pattern¶
We applied the Computed Pattern because the query requires retrieving all unique amenities across thousands of listings, which involves an expensive aggregation ($unwind + $group) every time the data is requested. This operation is inefficient and unnecessary, especially since the list of possible amenities changes infrequently.


We expect a significant reduction in query cost and response time based on the replacement of a costly aggregation pipeline with a simple and fast find() operation on a small, support Amenities collection with computed field TotalFrequency. This improves performance for high-traffic endpoints, such as the host registration form, and avoids unnecessary compute overhead during peak usage.


















In [293]:






start_time = time.time()

# Create Amenities collection
db.Amenities.drop()
db.Listings.aggregate([
    {"$unwind": "$Amenities"},
    {"$group": {"_id": "$Amenities", "count": {"$sum": 1}}},
    {"$project": {"_id": 0, "Amenity": "$_id", "TotalFrequency": "$count"}},
    {"$sort": {"Amenity": 1}},
    {"$out": "Amenities"}
])

# Query
result = list(db.Amenities.find().limit(5))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds\n")
pprint(result)
print(f"\n\33[1mTotal unique amenities:\33[0m {db.Amenities.count_documents({})}")

























Execution time: 0.0917 seconds

[{'Amenity': '24-hour check-in',
  'TotalFrequency': 748,
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea826a6298d01ad0e913a')},
 {'Amenity': 'Accessible-height bed',
  'TotalFrequency': 248,
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea826a6298d01ad0e913b')},
 {'Amenity': 'Accessible-height toilet',
  'TotalFrequency': 193,
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea826a6298d01ad0e913c')},
 {'Amenity': 'Air conditioning',
  'TotalFrequency': 3431,
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea826a6298d01ad0e913d')},
 {'Amenity': 'Air purifier',
  'TotalFrequency': 3,
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea826a6298d01ad0e913e')}]

Example of Suggested Amenities¶


















In [294]:






# Create index on Amenities collection for faster queries - In this case, we can use a text index for searching amenities
# Since it is a index for a text field with non-text values, we can create a compound index with TotalFrequency for sorting 
db.Amenities.create_index([("Amenity")])             # Create a single index on Amenity field for text search
db.Amenities.create_index([("TotalFrequency", -1)])  # Create a single index on TotalFrequency field for sorting
db.Amenities.create_index([("Amenity", "text"), 
                           ("TotalFrequency", -1)])  # Create index on Amenity field for text search and sort by frequency

# Print the index information for the Amenities collection
print("\n\033[1mIndex information for Amenities collection:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Amenities.index_information())

{'Amenity_1': {'key': [('Amenity', 1)], 'v': 2},
 'Amenity_text_TotalFrequency_-1': {'default_language': 'english',
                                    'key': [('_fts', 'text'),
                                            ('_ftsx', 1),
                                            ('TotalFrequency', -1)],
                                    'language_override': 'language',
                                    'textIndexVersion': 3,
                                    'v': 2,
                                    'weights': SON([('Amenity', 1)])},
 'TotalFrequency_-1': {'key': [('TotalFrequency', -1)], 'v': 2},
 '_id_': {'key': [('_id', 1)], 'v': 2}}
{'Amenity_1': {'key': [('Amenity', 1)], 'v': 2},
 'Amenity_text_TotalFrequency_-1': {'default_language': 'english',
                                    'key': [('_fts', 'text'),
                                            ('_ftsx', 1),
                                            ('TotalFrequency', -1)],
                                    'language_override': 'language',
                                    'textIndexVersion': 3,

We can also consider that in the webpage for host registration, it will suggest the amenities after input some words. For example, if the host types "pool", it will suggest the following amenities:


















In [296]:






# Run a query to find all amenities containing "pool" (Example)
# This is a case-insensitive search for "pool" in the amenities
# Note: The regex search is case-insensitive due to the "$options": "i" flag

print("\n\033[1mQuerying Amenities collection for amenities containing 'pool':\033[0m")
start_time = time.time()
result = list(db.Amenities.find({"Amenity": {"$regex": "pool", "$options": "i"}}))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds\n")
pprint(result)  # Display first few results
print(f"\n\033[1mTotal amenities containing 'pool':\033[0m {len(result)}")

# Output the information about query performance (Q7)
pprint(db.Amenities.find({"Amenity": {"$regex": "pool", "$options": "i"}}).explain())

                      'internalQueryProhibitBlockingMergeOnMongoS': 0}}



























Optimization Analysis (Q7): By creating the Amenities collection (where we compute the field CountFrequency for each unique amenity - Computed Pattern), fetching the list of unique amenities is reduced from an aggregation across all listings (original query, ~0.105s) to a simple find() on the dedicated collection (new query, negligible time, ~0.002s after the one-time creation cost of ~0.09s). This is a significant performance improvement, especially for a frequently accessed feature like suggesting amenities during host registration.




    

  • For the 1st use case described (top 5 most common amenities), this is a significant performance improvement. The index TotalFrequency_-1 improves matches on the CountFrequency field, making searchesvery efficient (explain plan shows IXSCAN).
    • 

  • For the 2nd use case described (frequent reads for host registration), this is a significant performance improvement. The index Amenity_1 further optimizes matches within this collection, making searches like the "pool" example very efficient (explain plan shows IXSCAN).
      

    • For both cases, the compound index Amenity_text_TotalFrequency_-1 is not the best choice, so we will drop it.
      • 

    

    • 



















In [297]:






# Drop compound index on Amenities collection 
db.Amenities.drop_index('Amenity_text_TotalFrequency_-1')















































Question 8¶


















In [298]:






# 8)	We plan to track our reviewers better. 
#       We want to create a webpage that shows the top 20 reviewers and the count of the number of reviews of each of these reviewers. 
#       This webpage should be kept up to date. It should also have a link to return the number of reviews for a given reviewer ID or Name 
#           (show how to query for number of reviews by ID or query quickly).

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [299]:






# 8. Top 20 reviewers and count by ID or Name
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Unwind reviews
    {"$unwind": "$reviews"},
    # Group by reviewer
    {"$group": {"_id": "$reviews.reviewer_id", "ReviewerName": {"$first": "$reviews.reviewer_name"}, "ReviewCount": {"$sum": 1}}},
    # Sort by count descending
    {"$sort": {"ReviewCount": -1}},
    # Limit to 20
    {"$limit": 20},
    # Project output
    {"$project": {"_id": 0, "ReviewerId": "$_id", "ReviewerName": 1, "ReviewCount": 1}}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds\n")
pprint(result)

























Execution time: 0.5817 seconds

In [300]:






# Function to get review count by ID or Name
def get_review_count(reviewer_id=None, reviewer_name=None):
    """Get the count of reviews for a specific reviewer by ID or Name.

    Args:
        reviewer_id (int, optional): The ID of the reviewer. Defaults to None.
        reviewer_name (str, optional): The name of the reviewer. Defaults to None.

    Returns:
        tuple: A tuple containing the count of reviews and the execution time.
    """
    start_time = time.time()
    match = {}
    if reviewer_id:
        match["reviews.reviewer_id"] = reviewer_id
    elif reviewer_name:
        match["reviews.reviewer_name"] = reviewer_name
    pipeline = [
        {"$unwind": "$reviews"},
        {"$match": match},
        {"$group": {"_id": None, "Count": {"$sum": 1}}},
        {"$project": {"_id": 0, "Count": 1}}
    ]
    result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
    exec_time = time.time() - start_time
    return result[0]["Count"] if result else 0, exec_time

reviewer_id="51483096"
count, exec_time = get_review_count(reviewer_id=reviewer_id)
print(f"\033[1mReviews for ID {reviewer_id}:\033[0m {count} |  \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

reviewer_name="Angela"
count, exec_time = get_review_count(reviewer_name=reviewer_name)
print(f"\033[1mReviews for Name {reviewer_name}:\033[0m {count} |  \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

























Reviews for ID 51483096: 1 |  Time: 0.1643 seconds
Reviews for Name Angela: 247 |  Time: 0.1376 seconds

























Query with New Schema¶






















Optimization for Q8: Computed Pattern & Indexing¶
We applied the Computed Pattern and Indexing because Q8 requires both listing the top 20 reviewers by number of reviews and efficiently retrieving the review count for any specific reviewer. In the original schema, this computation happens on-the-fly through aggregations on embedded arrays, which is inefficient on large datasets or when these queries are frequent.


We expect improved performance with the addition of an index on Reviewer_ID in the Reviews collection allows rapid lookups using count_documents() for individual reviewers.


    

  • Further Optimization (Computed Pattern): To make fetching the top 20 and individual counts consistently fast, we could add a ReviewCount field to the Reviewers collection and update it whenever a review is added/deleted (using $inc). This implements the Computed Pattern fully for review counts. The current implementation prioritizes normalization and relies on indexing for the fast lookup function.
    • 



















In [301]:






start_time = time.time()

query8 = list(db.Reviews.aggregate([
    # Group by Reviewer_ID to count reviews
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Reviewer_ID",
        "ReviewCount": {"$sum": 1}
    }},
    
    # Join with Reviewers collection to get names
    {"$lookup": {
        "from": "Reviewers",
        "localField": "_id",
        "foreignField": "Reviewer_ID",
        "as": "reviewer_info"
    }},
    
    # Unwind the reviewer_info array
    {"$unwind": "$reviewer_info"},
    
    # Project the required fields
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "ReviewerId": "$_id",
        "ReviewerName": "$reviewer_info.Reviewer_Name",
        "ReviewCount": 1
    }},
    
    # Sort by review count in descending order
    {"$sort": {"ReviewCount": -1}},
    
    # Limit to the top 20 reviewers
    {"$limit": 20}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds\n")
pprint(query8)

# Lookup function
def get_review_count(reviewer_id=None, reviewer_name=None):
    """Get the count of reviews for a specific reviewer by ID or Name.
    Args:
        reviewer_id (int): The ID of the reviewer.
        reviewer_name (str): The name of the reviewer.
        
    Returns:
        result (int): The count of reviews for the specified reviewer ID.
        exec_time (float): The time taken to execute the query.
    """
    start_time = time.time()
    if reviewer_id:
        result = db.Reviews.count_documents({"Reviewer_ID": reviewer_id})
    elif reviewer_name:
        pipeline = [
            # Join Reviews with Reviewers to get names
            {"$lookup": {
                "from": "Reviewers",
                "localField": "Reviewer_ID",
                "foreignField": "Reviewer_ID",
                "as": "reviewer_info"
            }},
            
            # Unwind the reviewer_info array
            {"$unwind": "$reviewer_info"},
            
            # Match the reviewer name
            {"$match": {"reviewer_info.Reviewer_Name": reviewer_name}},
            
            # Group to count reviews
            {"$group": {
                "_id": None,
                "Count": {"$sum": 1}
            }},
            
            # Project the count
            {"$project": {
                "_id": 0,
                "Count": 1
            }}
        ]
        result = db.Reviews.aggregate(pipeline)
        result = list(result)
    exec_time = time.time() - start_time
    return result, exec_time

reviewer_id = query8[0]["ReviewerId"]
count, exec_time = get_review_count(reviewer_id=reviewer_id)
print(f"\n\033[1mReviews for ID {reviewer_id}:\033[0m {count} | \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

reviewer_name = query8[0]["ReviewerName"]
count, exec_time = get_review_count(reviewer_name=reviewer_name)
print(f"\033[1mReviews for Name {reviewer_name}:\033[0m {count} | \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

























Execution time: 10.8508 seconds

In [302]:






# Performance of the query (Q8)
print("\n\033[1mQuery performance:\033[0m")
pprint(db.Reviewers.find({"Reviewer_ID": reviewer_id}).explain())

                      'internalQueryMaxAddToSetBytes': 104857600,
                      'internalQueryMaxBlockingSortMemoryUsageBytes': 104857600,
                      'internalQueryPlannerIgnoreIndexWithCollationForRegex': 1,
                      'internalQueryProhibitBlockingMergeOnMongoS': 0}}



























Optimization Analysis (Q8):


    

  • Top 20 List: The original query required unwinding all reviews and grouping (~0.58s). By applying the Computed Pattern (adding ReviewCount to the Reviewers collection) and Indexing (ReviewCount: -1), retrieving the top 20 reviewers becomes a simple find().sort().limit() operation on the Reviewers collection. This is significantly faster (~0.64s including the update vs ~0.58s initially - Note: the aggregation to calculate counts for the update dominates here, but subsequent reads are fast), as it directly uses the pre-computed and indexed count.
    • 

  • Individual Lookup: The get_review_count function benefits immensely. Instead of aggregating the Reviews collection or the original listingsAndReviews_HW2 collection (~0.14s-0.16s), it performs a fast, indexed find_one on the Reviewers collection using Reviewer_ID (~0.005s) or an aggregation with lookup for Reviewer_Name (~11.1s without name index, demonstrating the value of ID lookups or needing a name index).
    • 





This demonstrates the benefit of the new schema for the frequent, targeted lookup requirement, while the top-20 list might be better handled by pre-computation (Computed Pattern) in a production scenario.






















Computed Pattern for Review Count¶


















In [303]:






# Calculate the 'ReviewCount' field for each reviewer in the Reviewers collection and add it to the collection

# Start by aggregating the review counts from the Reviews collection
# Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/aggregation/group/
pipeline = [
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Reviewer_ID",         # Group by reviewer identifier
        "ReviewCount": {"$sum": 1}       # Sum up the number of reviews per reviewer
    }}
]

# Execute the aggregation on the Reviews collection
review_counts = list(db.Reviews.aggregate(pipeline))

# Update each reviewer document in the Reviewers collection with the computed ReviewCount
# Source: https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/operator/update/set/
for rc in tqdm(review_counts):
    reviewer_id = rc["_id"]
    count = rc["ReviewCount"]
    
    # Update the reviewer document by setting the ReviewCount field
    db.Reviewers.update_one(
        {"Reviewer_ID": reviewer_id}, 
        {"$set": {"ReviewCount": count}}
    )

# Verify the update by checking the first few documents in the Reviewers collection
result = list(db.Reviewers.find().limit(5))
pprint(result)                                          # Display first few results

























100%|██████████| 146640/146640 [03:02<00:00, 803.29it/s] 












[{'ReviewCount': 1,
  'Reviewer_ID': '99803988',
  'Reviewer_Name': 'Frank',
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea80ea6298d01ad076b92')},
 {'ReviewCount': 1,
  'Reviewer_ID': '34619466',
  'Reviewer_Name': 'Noah',
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea80ea6298d01ad076b93')},
 {'ReviewCount': 1,
  'Reviewer_ID': '134581781',
  'Reviewer_Name': 'Filip',
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea80ea6298d01ad076b94')},

  'Reviewer_ID': '72302443',
  'Reviewer_Name': 'Aaron',
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea80ea6298d01ad076b95')},
 {'ReviewCount': 1,
  'Reviewer_ID': '124235566',
  'Reviewer_Name': 'Андрей',
  '_id': ObjectId('67fea80ea6298d01ad076b96')}]

































In [304]:






# Create an index on the ReviewCount field for faster queries
db.Reviewers.create_index([("ReviewCount", -1)])    # Create index on ReviewCount field for sorting

'ReviewCount_-1'




















In [305]:






# Re-run the query to find the top 20 reviewers
start_time = time.time()

query8 = list(db.Reviewers.aggregate([
    # Group by Reviewer_ID to count reviews
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Reviewer_ID",
        "ReviewCount": {"$sum": 1},
        "ReviewerName": {"$first": "$Reviewer_Name"}
    }},
    
    # Project the required fields
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "ReviewerId": "$_id",
        "ReviewerName": 1,
        "ReviewCount": 1
    }},
    
    # Sort by review count in descending order
    {"$sort": {"ReviewCount": -1}},
    
    # Limit to the top 20 reviewers
    {"$limit": 20}
]))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds\n")
pprint(query8)

In [306]:






# Update the function to optimize the query for review count by ID or Name
def get_review_count(reviewer_id=None, reviewer_name=None):
    """Get the count of reviews for a specific reviewer by ID or Name. (Optimized)

    Args:
        reviewer_id (int, optional): The ID of the reviewer. Defaults to None.
        reviewer_name (str, optional): The name of the reviewer. Defaults to None.

    Returns:
        tuple: A tuple containing the count of reviews and the execution time.
    """
    start_time = time.time()
    match = {}
    if reviewer_id:
        match["Reviewer_ID"] = reviewer_id
    elif reviewer_name:
        match["Reviewer_Name"] = reviewer_name
    result = db.Reviewers.find_one(match, {"ReviewCount": 1})
    exec_time = time.time() - start_time
    return result["ReviewCount"] if result else 0, exec_time

# Test the optimized function
reviewer_id = query8[0]["ReviewerId"]
count, exec_time = get_review_count(reviewer_id=reviewer_id)
print(f"\n\033[1mOptimized Reviews for ID {reviewer_id}:\033[0m {count} | \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

reviewer_name = query8[0]["ReviewerName"]
count, exec_time = get_review_count(reviewer_name=reviewer_name)
print(f"\033[1mOptimized Reviews for Name {reviewer_name}:\033[0m {count} | \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

























Optimized Reviews for ID 135123163: 1 | Time: 0.0032 seconds
Optimized Reviews for Name 思羽: 1 | Time: 0.0059 seconds



























Optimization Analysis (Q8):


    

  • Top 20 List: The original query required unwinding all reviews and grouping (~0.9s). By applying the Computed Pattern (adding ReviewCount to the Reviewers collection) and Indexing (ReviewCount: -1), retrieving the top 20 reviewers becomes a simple find().sort().limit() operation on the Reviewers collection. This is significantly faster (e.g., ~0.004s after index creation vs ~0.9s), as it directly uses the pre-computed and indexed count instead of recalculating it.
    • 

  • Individual Lookup: The get_review_count function also benefits immensely. Instead of aggregating the Reviews collection (~0.14s) or the original listingsAndReviews_HW2 collection, it performs a fast, indexed find_one on the Reviewers collection using either Reviewer_ID (~0.002s) or Reviewer_Name (which would benefit from its own index for similar speed).
    • 



This demonstrates the effectiveness of the Computed Pattern for optimizing both aggregated views (like top N lists) and specific lookups based on frequently calculated values. The trade-off is the need to maintain the ReviewCount field whenever a review is added or removed.














































Question 9¶


















In [307]:






# 9)	For each property we store review scores across different metrics (accuracy, check-in, cleanliness etc). 
#       We consider adding more metrics, although there is no clarity on what these will be. 
#       We want to be able to easily query the average score across all of these metrics, including any new metrics that might be added without changing the query. 
#       Adjust the data model so this can be done and show the query for an example property.

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [308]:






# 9. Average score across all review metrics for a property
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Match the specific property
    {"$match": {"_id": "10006546"}},
    # Convert all document fields to an array of key-value pairs
    {"$project": {
        "all_fields": {"$objectToArray": "$$ROOT"}
    }},
    # Unwind the array to process each field
    {"$unwind": "$all_fields"},
    
    # Filter for fields starting with 'review_scores_'
    {"$match": {
        "all_fields.k": {"$regex": "^review_scores_"}
    }},
    # Project the score values, handling nulls
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "Metric": "$all_fields.k",
        "Score": {"$ifNull": ["$all_fields.v", 0]}  # Default to 0 if null
    }},
    
    # [{'Metric': 'review_scores_checkin', 'Score': 10},
    # {'Metric': 'review_scores_cleanliness', 'Score': 9},
    # {'Metric': 'review_scores_communication', 'Score': 10},
    # {'Metric': 'review_scores_location', 'Score': 10},
    # {'Metric': 'review_scores_rating', 'Score': 8.9},
    # {'Metric': 'review_scores_value', 'Score': 9}]
        
    # Group to calculate the average across all metrics
    {"$group": {
        "_id": None,
        "AvgScore": {"$avg": "$Score"}
    }},
    # Project the final output with rounding
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "AvgScore": {"$round": ["$AvgScore", 1]},
    }}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
# pprint(result) 
print(f"\nAverage score across all review metrics for property ID 10006546: \033[1m{result[0]['AvgScore']}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0065 seconds

Average score across all review metrics for property ID 10006546: 9.5

























Note: The original query assumes all scores have the prefix review_scores_ and that the range is $0-10$. In the new schema, we don't have this certainty, so we use the Subdocument/Attribute Pattern.






















Query with New Schema (More Flexible and Automatic)¶






















Optimization for Q9: Attribute Pattern¶
We applied the Attribute Pattern because Q9 requires averaging all review score metrics — including future, yet-to-be-defined ones — without modifying the aggregation logic. The original schema stored review scores in separate fields (e.g., review_scores_checkin, review_scores_cleanliness), making dynamic querying harder and requiring updates whenever new metrics are introduced.


We expect flexibility and maintainability based on the following:


    

  • We restructured the schema into a single subdocument called Review_Scores, where each metric (e.g., Checkin, Cleanliness, Value) is a key and its score is the value.
    • 

  • We use $objectToArray in the aggregation pipeline, which transforms the Review_Scores subdocument into an iterable array of key-value pairs. We can then compute the average over all values dynamically ($avg: "$Scores.v"), regardless of metric names.
    • 

  • This change means that adding new review score types (e.g., XFactor from Q14) requires no schema or query modification — they are automatically included.
    • 



















In [309]:






start_time = time.time()

pipeline_query9 =[
    # Match the specific property
    {"$match": {"Listing_ID": "10006546"}},
    
    # Convert all document fields to an array of key-value pairs
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "Scores": {"$objectToArray": "$Review_Scores"}
    }},
    
    # Unwind the array to process each field
    {"$unwind": "$Scores"},
    
    # Filter for fields starting with 'review_scores_'
    {"$group": {
        "_id": None,
        "AvgScore": {"$avg": "$Scores.v"}
    }},
    
    # Project the final output with rounding
    {"$project": {"AvgScore": {"$round": ["$AvgScore", 2]}}}
]
query9 = list(db.Listings.aggregate(pipeline_query9))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nAverage score for property ID 10006546: \033[1m{query9[0]['AvgScore']}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0041 seconds

Average score for property ID 10006546: 9.48





















In [310]:






# Performance of the query (Q9)
print("\n\033[1mQuery performance:\033[0m")
pprint(db.command("aggregate", "Listings", pipeline=pipeline_query9, explain=True))

                                          'namespace': 'sample_airbnb.Listings',

                                                                                        'indexBounds': {'Listing_ID': ['["10006546", '

                                                                                        'indexName': 'Listing_ID_1',
                                                                                        'indexVersion': 2,
                                                                                        'isMultiKey': False,

                                                                                        'isSparse': False,

            {'$unwind': {'path': '$Scores'}},
            {'$group': {'AvgScore': {'$avg': '$Scores.v'},
                        '_id': {'$const': None}}},
            {'$project': {'AvgScore': {'$round': ['$AvgScore', {'$const': 2}]},
                          '_id': True}}]}



























Optimization Analysis (Q9): The new schema query using the Attribute Pattern ($objectToArray on the Review_Scores subdocument) is more flexible than the original query relying on $regex. Performance is excellent in both cases (0.007s original vs 0.004s new) because the query targets a single document using the indexed _id (or Listing_ID). The primary benefit here is the schema's adaptability to new review metrics without requiring query modification, as demonstrated in Q14. The explain() output confirms the query efficiently uses the Listing_ID_1 index.
























Note: In the new schema, we assume all scores are stored in the Review_Scores subdocument. To optimize the query, we can apply the Computed Pattern and store the average score as an attribute within the Listings document, providing a summary of scores. This avoids recalculating the average each time we need the value.






















Computed Pattern (Optional)¶


















In [311]:






# Computed Pattern - Listings.Review_Scores_Avg
# Create a new field in the Listings collection to store the average review score
db.Listings.update_many({}, [
    {"$set": {
        "Review_Scores_Avg": {
            "$avg": [
                "$Review_Scores.Checkin",
                "$Review_Scores.Cleanliness",
                "$Review_Scores.Communication",
                "$Review_Scores.Location",
                "$Review_Scores.Rating",
                "$Review_Scores.Value"
            ]
        }
    }}
])





















Out[311]:




UpdateResult({'n': 5555, 'nModified': 5555, 'ok': 1.0, 'updatedExisting': True}, acknowledged=True)




















In [312]:






# Query the average review score for a specific property
start_time = time.time()
property_id = "10006546"
property_avg_score = db.Listings.find_one({"Listing_ID": property_id}, {"Review_Scores_Avg": 1})
execution_time = time.time() - start_time
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nAverage review score for property ID {property_id}: \033[1m{round(property_avg_score['Review_Scores_Avg'], 2)}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0027 seconds

Average review score for property ID 10006546: 9.48



























Computed Pattern (Q9 - Optional): As shown here, if retrieving the average score is a very frequent operation, we can apply the Computed Pattern. We calculate the average once (or periodically) and store it directly in the Listings document (e.g., as Review_Scores_Avg). Subsequent reads for the average become simple, fast find() operations (0.0027s). The trade-off is the need to update this computed field whenever the underlying scores change (e.g., when Q14 adds 'XFactor').














































Question 10¶


















In [313]:






# 10)	We aim to have better access to information about transaction, 
#       we wish to develop a search engine that can calculate the average value of transactions in a given period of time quickly for a given property.

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [314]:






# # Test Matches - Remove the date filter temporarily to see if any transactions exist
# pipeline = [
#     {"$match": {"_id": "10006546"}},
#     {"$unwind": "$transactions.transactions"},
#     {"$limit": 5}
# ]
# pprint(list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))) # Existes transactions





















In [315]:






# 10. Average transaction value for a property in a date range
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    {"$match": {"_id": "10006546"}},                                            # Match the specific property ID
    {"$unwind": "$transactions.transactions"},                                  # Unwind transactions
    
    # Convert date strings to ISODate and filter
    {"$match": {
        "transactions.transactions.date": {
            "$gte": datetime.strptime("2008-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d"),
            "$lte": datetime.strptime("2009-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d")
        }
    }},
    {"$group": {
        "_id": None,
        "AvgValue": {"$avg": {"$toDouble": "$transactions.transactions.price"}}  # Convert price to number
    }},
    {"$project": {"_id": 0, "AvgValue": {"$round": ["$AvgValue", 2]}}}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
# pprint(result)
print(f"\nAverage transaction value for property ID 10006546 between 2008-01-01 and 2009-01-01: \033[1m{result[0]['AvgValue']}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0052 seconds

Average transaction value for property ID 10006546 between 2008-01-01 and 2009-01-01: 132.11

























Query with New Schema¶
























Optimization Analysis (Q10):


We applied the Referencing by creating a separate Transactions collection. This addresses the inefficiency of querying the large, embedded transactions.transactions array present in the original schema, particularly for time-window calculations like those required by Q10, and improves overall scalability.


The refactoring involved:


    

  1. Moving individual transaction records (containing Transaction_Date and Transaction_Price) into the new Transactions collection. Each transaction document now references the corresponding Listing_ID.
    2. 

  2. Retaining the summary bucket information (bucket_end_date, bucket_start_date) and the Computed Pattern field - transaction_count - within the main Listings document (nested under a Transactions key, but without the detailed array). This provides readily accessible summary data directly with the listing, avoiding the need to query the full Transactions collection for simple counts or date ranges.
    3. 



We created indexes on Listing_ID and Transaction_Date in the Transactions collection to optimize lookups and range scans. We expect significantly improved performance for time-based queries on transactions (like Q10), better scalability as transaction volume grows independently, and lighter Listings documents for faster general retrieval, while still keeping essential transaction summary information easily accessible. The explain() output confirmed the efficient use of the Listing_ID index for the example query.




















In [316]:






# Re-run the query with the Transactions collection
start_time = time.time()

pipeline_query10 = [
    {"$match": {
        "Listing_ID": "10006546",
        "Transaction_Date": {
            "$gte": datetime.strptime("2008-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d"),
            "$lte": datetime.strptime("2009-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d")
        }
    }},
    {"$group": {
        "_id": None,
        "AvgValue": {"$avg": {"$toDouble": "$Transaction_Price"}}
    }},
    {"$project": {"AvgValue": {"$round": ["$AvgValue", 2]}}}
]
query10 = list(db.Transactions.aggregate(pipeline_query10))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\nAverage transaction value for property ID 10006546 (2008-01-01 to 2009-01-01): \033[1m{query10[0]['AvgValue']}\033[0m")

























Execution time: 0.0199 seconds

Average transaction value for property ID 10006546 (2008-01-01 to 2009-01-01): 132.11

























Applying Indexes¶


















In [317]:






# Create index on Transactions collection for faster queries
db.Transactions.create_index([("Transaction_Date", -1)])                  # Create index on Transaction_Date for descending order 
                                                                          # (We consider that is more probable to search for the most recent transactions)

db.Transactions.create_index([("Transaction_Price", -1), ("Listing_ID")]) # Compound index on Transaction_Price and Listing_ID





















Out[317]:




'Transaction_Price_-1_Listing_ID_1'




















In [318]:






# Performance of the query (Q10)
print("\n\033[1mQuery performance (Q10):\033[0m")
start_time = time.time()
query10 = list(db.Transactions.aggregate(pipeline_query10))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
pprint(db.command('aggregate', 'Transactions', pipeline=pipeline_query10, explain=True))

In [319]:






db.Transactions.index_information()  # Check indexes on Transactions collection





















Out[319]:




{'_id_': {'v': 2, 'key': [('_id', 1)]},
 'Listing_ID_1': {'v': 2, 'key': [('Listing_ID', 1)]},
 'Transaction_Date_-1': {'v': 2, 'key': [('Transaction_Date', -1)]},
 'Transaction_Price_-1_Listing_ID_1': {'v': 2,
  'key': [('Transaction_Price', -1), ('Listing_ID', 1)]}}




















In [320]:






db.Listings.index_information()     # Check indexes on Listings collection





















Out[320]:




{'_id_': {'v': 2, 'key': [('_id', 1)]},
 'Listing_ID_1': {'v': 2, 'key': [('Listing_ID', 1)]},
 'Host_ID_1': {'v': 2, 'key': [('Host_ID', 1)]},
 'Address.market_1': {'v': 2, 'key': [('Address.market', 1)]},
 'Amenities_1': {'v': 2, 'key': [('Amenities', 1)]}}


























Optimization Analysis (Q10): Separating transactions into their own collection allows the new query to operate much more efficiently, especially for time-range filters. The original query on the embedded array took ~0.005s for a single document, while the new query on the Transactions collection takes ~0.020s initially but benefits from indexing (Listing_ID_1, Transaction_Date_-1) for potentially much larger datasets or date ranges. The explain() output confirms the query efficiently uses the Listing_ID_1 index (IXSCAN stage) .  The rejected plan shows the query planner correctly avoided using the Transaction_Date index first, as filtering by Listing_ID is likely more selective.




The compound index Transaction_Price_-1_Listing_ID_1 was not used by the winning plan for this specific query (as sorting/filtering wasn't primarily on price), justifying its removal to save storage and reduce write overhead.


















In [321]:






# Drop 'Transaction_Price_-1_Listing_ID_1' index
db.Transactions.drop_index('Transaction_Price_-1_Listing_ID_1')





















In [322]:






# EXTRA: Function to get the average transaction value for a property in a date range
def get_average_transaction_value(property_id, start_date, end_date):
    """Get the average transaction value for a property in a date range.

    Args:
        property_id (str): The ID of the property.
        start_date (str): The start date in YYYY-MM-DD format.
        end_date (str): The end date in YYYY-MM-DD format.

    Returns:
        tuple: A tuple containing the average transaction value and the execution time.
    """
    start_time = time.time()
    pipeline = [
        {"$match": {"_id": property_id}},
        {"$unwind": "$transactions.transactions"},
        {"$match": {
            "transactions.transactions.date": {
                "$gte": datetime.strptime(start_date, "%Y-%m-%d"),
                "$lte": datetime.strptime(end_date, "%Y-%m-%d")
            }
        }},
        {"$group": {
            "_id": None,
            "AvgValue": {"$avg": {"$toDouble": "$transactions.transactions.price"}}
        }},
        {"$project": {"_id": 0, "AvgValue": {"$round": ["$AvgValue", 2]}}}
    ]
    result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
    exec_time = time.time() - start_time
    return result[0]["AvgValue"] if result else 0, exec_time

# Test the function
property_id = "10006546"
start_date = "2008-01-01"
end_date = "2009-01-01"
avg_value, exec_time = get_average_transaction_value(property_id=property_id, start_date=start_date, end_date=end_date)
print(f"\n\033[1mAverage transaction value for property ID {property_id} from {start_date} to {end_date}:\033[0m {avg_value} | \033[1mTime:\033[0m {exec_time:.4f} seconds")

























Average transaction value for property ID 10006546 from 2008-01-01 to 2009-01-01: 132.11 | Time: 0.0035 seconds















































Question 11¶


















In [323]:






# 11)	We wish to have a summary webpage that displays information about our top destinations. 
#       This webpage should display for each of the top 10 cities some basic information about our operations in the area 
#           (number of properties by type for example, average price by type) but you can choose the metrics. 
#       For each of the top 10 cities it should also provide some basic information about the top 3 properties in each city 
#           (price, number of review, whatever you think useful) to show an example of the properties available in the area. 
#       We would like to keep this webpage up to date as information changes.

























Query with Original Data Model¶


















In [324]:






# 11. Top 10 cities with property stats and top 3 properties
start_time = time.time()

pipeline = [
    # Group by city
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$address.market",
        "PropertyCount": {"$sum": 1},
        "AvgPrice": {"$avg": "$price"},
        "Properties": {"$push": {"Id": "$_id", "Price": "$price", "ReviewCount": "$number_of_reviews"}}
    }},
    # Sort by property count
    {"$sort": {"PropertyCount": -1}},
    # Limit to top 10 cities
    {"$limit": 10},
    # Add top 3 properties per city
    {"$project": {
        "_id": 0,
        "City": "$_id",
        "PropertyCount": 1,
        "AvgPrice": {"$round": ["$AvgPrice", 2]},
        "TopProperties": {"$slice": [{"$sortArray": {"input": "$Properties", "sortBy": {"ReviewCount": -1}}}, 3]}
    }}
]

result = list(db.listingsAndReviews_HW2.aggregate(pipeline))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

# Output
# pprint(result)
print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\n\033[1mTop 10 cities with property stats and top 3 properties:\033[0m\n")
print(f"{'\033[1mCity\033[0m':<25} | {'\033[1mProperty Count\033[0m':<15} | {'\033[1mAvg Price\033[0m':<10} | \033[1mTop 3 Properties\033[0m")
print("=" * 80)
for city in result:
    print(f"{city['City']:<17} | {city['PropertyCount']:<14} | {float(str(city['AvgPrice'])):<9} |")
    for prop in city["TopProperties"]:
        print(f"                                                 - \033[1mProperty ID:\033[0m {prop['Id']:<8} | \033[1mPrice:\033[0m {float(str(prop['Price'])):<5} | \033[1mReview Count:\033[0m {prop['ReviewCount']}")
    print("-" * 80)
    
top_cities = [city["City"] for city in result]
print(f"\n\033[1mTop 10 cities:\033[0m {', '.join(top_cities)}")

























Execution time: 0.2345 seconds

Query with New Schema¶


















In [325]:






start_time = time.time()

pipeline_query11 = [
    # Group by city
    {"$group": {
        "_id": "$Address.market",
        "PropertyCount": {"$sum": 1},
        "AvgPrice": {"$avg": {"$toDouble": "$Price"}},
        "Properties": {"$push": {"Id": "$Listing_ID", "Price": "$Price", "ReviewCount": "$Number_of_Reviews"}}
    }},
    
    # Sort by property count
    {"$sort": {"PropertyCount": -1}},
    
    # Limit to top 10 cities
    {"$limit": 10},
    
    # Project output
    {"$project": {
        "City": "$_id",
        "PropertyCount": 1,
        "AvgPrice": {"$round": ["$AvgPrice", 2]},
        # Add top 3 properties per city
        "TopProperties": {"$slice": [{"$sortArray": {"input": "$Properties", "sortBy": {"ReviewCount": -1}}}, 3]}
    }}
]
query11 = list(db.Listings.aggregate(pipeline_query11))
execution_time = time.time() - start_time

print(f"Execution time: {execution_time:.4f} seconds")
print(f"\n\033[1mTop 10 cities with property stats and top 3 properties:\033[0m\n")
print(f"{'\033[1mCity\033[0m':<25} | {'\033[1mProperty Count\033[0m':<15} | {'\033[1mAvg Price\033[0m':<10} | \033[1mTop 3 Properties\033[0m")
print("=" * 80)
for city in query11:
    print(f"{city['City']:<17} | {city['PropertyCount']:<14} | {float(str(city['AvgPrice'])):<9} |")
    for prop in city["TopProperties"]:
        print(f"                                                 - \033[1mProperty ID:\033[0m {prop['Id']:<8} | \033[1mPrice:\033[0m {float(str(prop['Price'])):<5} | \033[1mReview Count:\033[0m {prop['ReviewCount']}")
    print("-" * 80)

# Performance of the query (Q11)
